If you're at a table full of nits who don't pay off (players like T.J., for example) then you shouldn't waste your money with the small pairs, unless you're simply trying to steal the pot pre-flop (basically playing it like a semi-bluff).Overall, I was very disappointed with this book.  I think the main problem is it's target audience, or lack thereof.  It seems like the authors wrote this with serious poker players in mind, but it reads more like a beginners book.  If I had found this a few years back when I played ATC (any two cards) this would have been exactly what I needed.  Now that I know how to play the good kind of loose, this book does nothing for me.If you're a real tight player, you may find this book comforting.  Everyone else should move along; there's nothing to see here.  If this is "the bible of poker", as the back cover claims, then call me an atheist, cause I ain't buying it.

The stories throughout are worth the price alone.  Add to that Cloutier (& Mcevoy) giving sound poker advice, and you get a book to look at for years to come.The book is focused on both pot limit and no limit, and the advise is split evenly throughout.  It offers a ton of strategy, practice hands and different view points (Cloutier and McEvoy are both great players, but play certain hands very differently).  The writing is such that you feel that TJ is sitting next to you, telling you how to play - - an aspect that I really enjoyed.  The book ends with tails from TJ, a collection of poker memories from his days traveling from game to game throughout Texas.
summary: Very good book, with advice from a poker legend

reviewText: I bought this book. The book is written in a very informal style. However, the first day after I read it I finished 6th out of 1600 in one tournement in which I never finished higher than 400 in before. This guy knows his stuff, but do you have the discipline and patience to follow his advice? This is not a formula book, as in play this way, and this way only. TJ goes into the real aspect of NL tourny play, as in playing the player, and not making mistakes. I would rather you not read this book because I don't want anyone who follows it to play against me. But if you do read it pay attention, TJ's style is understated to say the least, but he lays out a system that will win you tournaments.

I'm a good limit and decent NL player, winning at both regularly.  I wanted to take my game to the next level and this book did not help.  There are no tricks or even organized suggestions in this book.  It is a bunch of chat basically about being tight.  I also bought Internet texas hold'em by Matthew Hilger and that book taught me tons.  In fact my NL play improved as much from that book as it did from TJ's.  Overall this book is a huge disappointment.  It is repetetive and full of chatter which is interesting but can't improve your game.  Send me $50 and I will tell you not to play KJ and Q10 in a NL game.
summary: Don't know why this book gets high reviews

reviewText: As the title implies, the authors discuss every hand that [they] think is playable in a tourney and describe how to play them in limit, no-limit and pot-limit events. There's also a discussion of some important hands that were played in past WSOP championship events. However, I found the information and discussion to be a bit shallow.McEvoy and Cloutier seem to take a cookie cutter approach when describing how to play the hands. When you have hand X you do action Y. While they [somtimes] modify the action to be taken based on position, there is almost no discussion of the changes that your stack size would dictate. Nor is there much discussion of how hands play differently early in the tournament at full tables vs. late at short tables.Discussion of how to play various hands on the flop and later are seldom given much in-depth discussion.Anyone following the advice would be fairly predictable.Lastly it should be noted that the authors are two long-time successful players. While overall I was disappointed, there were a few points that struck me as very useful. Hence the two stars instead of one.

Before reading this book, I was a decent NL holdem player, playing up to the $2/4NL games.  I was a money making player, but i found that i was often playing extremely inconsistently, often losing my entire initial 400 buy-in, then having to climb the ladder back up, which i was usually able to do, although with much anguish and lack of patience.This book took me to the next level.  It clearly explained differences between starting hands in nolimit holdem and reasons why other hands (ie k/j q/j a/j) are trash.  Although i had won plenty of money playing those hands in the past, i found that those hands were "leaks" in my game, as i would sometimes lose everything with them.  I found that i was playing too many hands and overvaluing certain other hands like a/k.Another aspect of this book that is not usually covered as well in other books is how to play your monster starting hand after the flop; how to be creative with your hands against different types of players; how to extract that last dime from yoru opponents.As johnny cash puts it, "You got to know when to hold 'em; know when to fold 'em. Know when to walk away..."
summary: took my game to a new level

reviewText: being that tj is one of the most respected no limit players and Mcevoy is no slouch himself, i thought their championship no limit book would be a necessary tool in my continual efforts to improve my game.  it is not!  more of a book of short stories with limited poker reasoning, analysis, etc.  it is amazing how many pages of this book you can read without gaining any information on proper play/strategy (literally, you take nothing away).  if you still think this is a must have after my review, contact me, and i'll send you my copy for free, with only one cauveate(sp?), no sendbacks!  you'll have to find someone else to send it too!  msy
summary: short stories not educational - AVOID if trying to improve game

reviewText: Great book but it is a reprint.  Wish I had known since I already had it.  Woof.

If you occassionally find yourself playing hands other than AA, KK, or AK, there isn't much instruction in this book that can't be summed up with the usual "play tight, be aggressive".  Certainly mastering it will not allow you to quit your job and play poker full time.Some pretty funny stories, though.
summary: Some funny stories, but not densely packed with good advice

reviewText: The flood of players coming into poker is overwhelming and the books to learn poker are many. Keep in mind that what looks like the same game is actually quite different. Low stakes limit holdem is much different than high stakes limit holdem and no limit and pot limit are significantly different than limit holdem. And finally no limit cash is different than no limit tournament play. That said this book is excellent for pot limit and even more so for no limit mid to high buy in tournaments.A quick hint- the use of the word "Championship" in the McEvoy and Cloutier titles can and should be completely interchangeable with the word "tournament". That is the player these books are written for.Many of the super tight approaches that Cloutier uses to be successful in tournament play are unprofitable in cash game play. Because the average player is so ultra loose, tighter is probably better than looser but again this is geared primarily for tournaments where if you lose your chips you are through for the day.Survival is one of the most important ideas in tournament play but ultra tight in cash games will often get you too little action on your better hands. Overall a very good book for tournament play; Cloutier is a proven and durable winner and has much to teach the budding no limit holdem  tournament player in this book. Several now well-known winners have credited this book as "the" reason they won. Worth reading IMO.
summary: you need to know what game you are playing

reviewText: Judging from the other reviews I've read, I'm different from most other reviewers. I'm not a no-limit hold'em player. I'm a pot-limit player, and there's a big, big difference. This book highlights the difference, and it provides sound foundations for pot-limit strategy and play. I'm not going to go into great detail. Other reviewers have done a good job of that, and I doubt I could so any better. Suffice it to say that whether you play no-limit or pot-limit this book will be an excellent addition to your poker library. It helped me improve my play. Shortly after reading the book and digesting the information I placed 2nd out of 889 players in a pot-limit tournament. I'd not done better than 22nd out of 400 before, on my best day.The information in the book is solid and will help, if you let it.
summary: Excellent value for the money. Very good book for poker players.

reviewText: This is an excellent book on pot limit and no limit hold'em, but the title can be misinterpreted.  When it comes to side games, the pot limit section is very helpful, but the no limit talk pretty much covers tournament play, specifically the WSOP.  For no limit side games, I would recommend Super/System.  Doyle and TJ seem to agree on most points, such as being careful with AA or KK etc. with only a few discrepancies, but they are different players with different styles.  The only other benefit for side games that TJ's book has is that he gives more detail in  the reasoning for why AJ, AQ, etc are high risk hands, but Doyle does cover it too.Get this book, but if you want to play side games, get Super/System too.

I think maybe I have read too many books on poker now. I didn't see anything new here.  Basically, it says know your players and play really tight.  They don't like suited aces, suited connectors, or overcards suited or not, I would like to watch a tournament from start to finish to see if Cloutier plays just aces.
there is some good stuff in this book and written in simple terms

I must admit this is one essential poker book that should be in every poker player's library. Tj and Tom give you expert analysis on the proper way to play particular hands. I really value their experience given all the bracelets and tournaments they've both won. Tj Cloutier gives great advice on knowing your opponents and tendencies to make your decisions at the poker table. Even though much of the advice in this book at first look can be interpreted as conservative, its really the best book on tournament poker strategy. Tj stresses no limit holdem is all about survival and making smart decisions where you don't have to take too many chances will ensure you do survive. For example Tj states "In the first round of the World Series, as well as in the first round of the smaller buy-in events at the WSOP, a pair of kings is not a big enough hand to get broke with. The only hand that is big enough to get broke with before the flop is two aces." Who'd a thought that at first glance!

I bought this book along with sklansky theory of poker, brunson super system and mike caro pro book of tells. This book is definately worth a read though does lean on the tight side of playing. I wouldn't recommend Sklansky because it really is too theoretical, super system is a great text book for dipping in and out of, and I wouldn't recommend Caro pro tells to anyone because it is a great book which should be kept a secret by anyone who gets to read it!!!Cloutier/Mcevoy is a good intermediate level booster. The stories at the end are worthless and a wasted chapter just to fill up space which is a let down as I was expecting some really cool poker/gambling anecdotes and stories.
This is mostly a rehash of general tournament advice.  If you read everything, you will want to read this, since it is good advice.  But if you are pretty experienced, you probably won't learn much.

I bought this based on the snippets that they give you here on Amazon.  The actual C.D. is much better than even the previews give you.  It gives you energy, makes you want to get up and dance and twirl around with your hands over your head.  It's also great to listen in the car, it makes any trip go by very quickly.  My advice would be to buy it, it's one of the best Kirtan C.D.'s I've heard yet.  The first C.D. is very fast paced and the second is more mellow, more open to interpretation.

I am a big fan of McEvoy's books, probably because I tend to play poker in more or less the same fashion that he does and also generally specialize in tournament play.  This book is good, but not on par with some of his other books, such as Championship Poker, etc.  I think my biggest disappointment was two-fold:  There was a substantial chunk of the book devoted to satellite and super satellite play for limit events (which I don't play at all, and seems on the fringes since most premier events are no limit), and the section on internet satellite play was small.  I would have liked to see more content there, especially since this is where most people buying this book will be playing there satellite play.  Yes we all know how Moneymaker turned $39 into $2.5M, but it would have been nice to have more in-depth discussion about accomplishing that, especially in extremely low-buy in super satellites with large fields.  I did find some useful information in this book I hadn't found elsewhere (the mark of a good poker book in my opinion) so I would recommend it to anyone thinking about using some portion of their poker bankroll as a springboard into large, big-money tournaments.
summary: Not as good as his other books but worth a read

reviewText: Saved money going to a professional, and time from having to start from scratch.  Recommend for every health club type business
This is ok but it's not very relaxing... I would classify this music as a bollywood soundtrack.
summary: Nice, but not relaxing music... too bollywood

reviewText: Jai has a great voice. I'm turning all of my friends on to this music. The pet bird was even dancing to it. Very inspirational. I love both cd's.
summary: Kirtan: The Art and Practice of Ecstatic Chant

reviewText: Wonderful kirtan, by a great artist.
summary: Kirtan: The Art and Practice of Ecstatic Chant by jai Uttal

reviewText: I am biased, extremely so.  I went to a retreat with Jai Uttal, and I had one of the most wonderful times of my life.  When I left, I went into severe Kirtan withdrawals; so I went to my local bookstore and bought "Kirtan: The Art and Practice of Ecstatic Chant"Admittedly, chanting with a CD was not as beautiful as chanting with friends at the foot of Mount Jefferson in Oregon while Jai sat in front of us completely lost in his music.  Nevertheless, I chanted along with the CD.  And I and then I chanted some more.  I chanted all the time.  I even chanted in my dreams, seriously.Rahde, Radhe Govinda.  I had no idea what the words meant, nor did I really care.  The more I chanted, the happier I felt.  I was not even a Hindu and I still felt happy.  The simple mantras sunk into my heart and I made them mine, literally.I got out my guitar and started banging away with the CD.  I became interested in the meaning of the words.  And I became interested in the Hindu religion.  I studied, and I am happy to say that my increased knowledge of Kirtan did not ruin my enjoyment of it.  I am still not a Hindu.  But I love these chants and I love this CD.  I loved it so much that I gave it a friend.  Now I better go buy another one.  I miss it.The only thing I didn't like about the CD is that Jai didn't play his harmonium.  He is a good harmonium player.  Jai, what were you thinking of?  And it could have used a little harp music, as in harmonica.  And, Jai, you may not know this, but I play the harp, not that I'm suggesting anything.Thank you, John C. Conley, author of "Letters to My Friends: A No Guarantees Guide to Awakening."
summary: I am becoming addicted to Kirtan

reviewText: Jai is wonderful. Ganesha Shanaram plays in my head all day and I feel happy. Even my granddaughter dances with me when it plays. Very cool.
This is nice to listen to but I was wanting a CD of call and response chanting for the purpose of chanting with friends.
This is the best chanting CD I've ever heard.  I will definently be buying more from this artist!  The voices fill you with life and energy.
Purchased this CD based on a piece about the artist on NPR.  Great music selections for yoga practice and massage.
His simple rhythms, melodies and interesting vocals make this a great listen for Bhakti Yogaholics and Mantra Maniacs.I enjoy it daily and cannot give it higher praise than that.
This is just superb ... very peaceful, uplifting and devotional.Highly recommended !Jai Uttal is great and has also explained very well.
What a great CD.  I recommend if you love Indian chants you got to have this in your collection.  I love it.
This is a great intro CD to Kirtan. The songs on this CD are beautiful. If you are looking for beautiful chants over rhthmic music, you will enjoy this CD.
Awesome relaxing music that transcends time and space... and the first bayan by the child is so cute!  Love it!

These cds were truly an unexpected blessing! Jai's sound runs deep & promotes inward dwelling in the purest sense. Jai's sound is all heart and awakens the soul gently through sensuous, rich, universal love. These cds are by far the best pieces of music I have ever heard..Namaste, Caterina
summary: Kirtan: The Art and Practice of Ecstatic Chant

reviewText: Jai Uttal's voice reminds me of an old bluesman at times... Fantastic, lush, hypnotic arrangements. Layered, psychedelic kirtan music. Takes you somewhere else...
This book could be better if it was also for beginners, too.  I had to buy another book and put it away for a while.
I really love Jai's voice, it's soothing and transcendent. A great album for anyone who loves kirtan.Very informative  too.

Don't bother spending your money on this.  The five pages on satellites in Lindgren's book far outweigh any content in this...its mostly just stories of past satellites with some obvious advice thrown in (auto-checking online is a tell!!! thanks for that)

This is the most beautiful music I have ever heard. I have listened to the CD over 100 times and it sounds better every time. Kirtan is great to sing along to, and this is a modern version of the ancient practice. BUY THIS CD.

Jai Uttal is the real deal.  He's an accomplished musician and singer who was one of the first Westerners to popularize Kirtan, which is (more often than not) Hindu chanting done in a call and response fashion.  Some modern Kirtan players recreate Indian melodies and style.  Jai Uttal sounds at once authentic and modern.  His influences range from reggae to rock to bossa nova to everything else.  His voice has range, power, and depth. He has found a genre he loves and has done it great honor. I gues the highest compliment I can give this one is that no matter how often I play it, I never get tired of it.  Only about 5-10 CD's in my life have given me that experience.

This is one of the BEST albums I have ever listened to. It is so incredibly moving!  His voice, the music, its beautiful and uplifting.  You will not be dissapointed.  My favorite is Radha Rani becuase it is inspirational.  I feel bliss when I listen to that song.  You are missing out if you don't get this album.  Thank you Jai!!!!!

If you have never been to the WSOP and plan to play a satellite for your entry you should read through this book at least once.  While the online sections can leave a little to be desired, there isn't much difference it strategy or information, I recommend this book to anyone with questions about satellite play.  It will cover your basics and break down each tournment into stages so you can focus on one piece at a time.

Although a double CD set, both disks pose a problem to this reviewer's taste. Each contains a rather lengthy exposition by the artist on the nature of Bhakti (Devotional) Yoga sandwiched in the program. Jai Uttal has a very pleasant speaking voice & the material was helpful, even inspiring--but do you really want to hear it all over again everytime you play either discs? I know I don't. The musical material is engaging, but not  particularly special. It is authentic mantra, but without the technical brilliance of many such CDs (see links below). I don't regret buying it--again, BUT it won't become a treasured favorite. I don't think it would turn-on people who weren't mantra fanatics like me or a real fan of the artist--or a devotee of Kirtan.PS. The cover artwork is great!Greatest Hits of the Kali YugaBreath of the HeartChants Of India: Ravi Shankar; George HarrisonThe Essential Ravi ShankarThe Sounds of IndiaThe Sounds of IndiaPeter Brook's The MahabharataDVDDeviThe Bhagavad Gita
summary: Not As Ecstatic As I Like To Be

reviewText: I have other Jai Uttal releases, but this has a twist, and is well worth adding to you collection.

This 2-CD set is one of the best introductions to contemporary kirtan I've come across (and I own many kirtan CDs). Aside from the wonderful spoken section, where Jai Uttal chats informally about what kirtan is, the selection of songs is truly heartwarming. I love both CDs, but find I listen over and over again particularly to the second one for its variety of moods and styles. Jai's voice really cuts deep and brings out the intensity and authenticity of his own devotion to the path of music and the heart.In addition, the musicianship of everyone featured on this set is superb and adds so much to the listening experience. It is hard not to sing along and feel the blessings flow, even if you are not a singer...and that is exactly the point.

Kirtan is the perfect antidote to all the dark, angry music that's coming out these days.  It's spirit-centered music that carries you to a higher place.  Let Jai Uttal (one of kirtan's best artists ever) teach you how to chant.  It's pure pleasure for the soul.
It is amazing. Melodious and sung from the heart. Where can I get more of same stuff?PK
Jai opens a gate to the lower Beriatic World and Bliss descends upon the hearer's consciousness like a gentle rain. Addictive!

I don't know anything about "chant" but I do know that I really enjoy this man's voice and musical sensibility.  The first CD has several minutes of him describing what it is that he's doing, why, the meaning, etc., and it's relaxing and enjoyable just listening to him.  He has a great voice, he's obviously very involved, interested, and knowledgable about the material, and you don't have to work hard at listening through an accent if you're American (truly hearing everything a person is saying when they have a thick accent is so exhausting... and I WANT to hear everything a person has to say!).For those of you who don't know, this "chant" is basically songs that don't have a lot of lyrics; that is, it's pretty much the same thing over and over, except most of us don't know what he's saying!  Ha!  But that's okay, trust me on this.  It's beautiful and it's not boring.  He does this really really well.And what I find striking, in addition, is this sheer joy that he obviously has which is really coming out in the music, which may sound hokey, but after a rough day in the corporate world, on the often not-so-enjoyable commute home, believe me, it feels really good to hear.If you're looking for something different, done really well, I'd definitely give this a try.

I would give this CD 10 stars if I could. I listen when I paint, cook, relax, drive, anything. It is inspiring and makes me feel actually "closer" to spirit. His voice and talent aregifts from God. Highly recommended. My 5 and 11 year old even love it.
Beautiful CD and inspiring.  Heard it first at a Yoga training and it felt like arriving back at home.For Yoga or just chill, this is a must have!
When the CD arrived the plastic casing was completely smashed. The CD luckily was intact and not damaged from the broken plastic casing, however I was unhappy that the packing was inadequate.

This CD is a beautiful compilation of Kirtan.  I don't know much about Neem Karoli Baba.  I noticed on the leaf jacket for the CD that Jai Uttal is a sishya of Neem Karoli Baba.  Krishna Das is also a sishya of Neem Karoli Baba.  Perhaps that is why there is so much bhajanananda felt from their kirtans.  I loved the work on his CD "Music for Yoga and Other Joys".  I don't resonate so well with the choir vocals in the kirtan on this CD.

When I heard an interview on NPR with this artist,Jai Uttal,and music from his CD I couldn't get it out of my mind.  It is "a joyful noise" that lifts the spirit and energizes.  His very personal explanation of Kirtan on Track 2 gives one an understanding of the spiritual basis of the music and even if it is not a path that you might follow you can't help but be swept up in the chanting.  I play it in the car on days when I feel stressed and it removes all that chatter in my head and helps me arrive at my destination uplifted and in the present. His interpretation of the ancient chants using non traditional instruments and renditions is appealing and engaging. P.S.It is a 2 disc set so you can have one at home and one in the car!
it's an ok map. water proof is a plus.  the map "Bob Marshall Wilderness Complex: North Half" is much better in what i was looking for/interested in.

This CD is beautiful. It's worth buying just to listen to Jai's voice. He's got something incredible in his voice. Though I don't care for the talking track and often just skip it, the quality of the kirtan and music is 5+ stars! Jai's voice comes from some incredible place and is really moving. This CD is one of the best solid kirtan albums I've ever seen-- reminds me of the quality of the kirtan CD by Ragani called Best of Both Worlds-- good instrumentation, great vocals, no hype. CD's like these are meant to be listened to over and over again. They'll fill you and leave you deeply inspired. I'm so glad he did this CD!

I was a big fan of Krishna Das and I still am. A couple of weeks ago, for the first time in my life, I heard Jai Uttal's 'Radha Rani ki Jai, Maha Rani ki Jai' - Track # 4 on Disc 2. Like all good music does to my soul, I was so enchanted that I played the same track again and again till I lost count. I wasted no time in getting both the discs and my favorites are as follows:Disc 1: Track # 3 'Radha Govinda'Disc 2: Track # 1 'Durga Pahimam', Track # 3 'Jaya Radha', Track # 4 'Radha Rani'Originally coming from India and being a big proponent of 'Bhakthi Yoga' (Path of devotion and Divine love for God), I can say from the depths of my heart that Jai Uttal sings with such soulful melody and love, it takes my breath away every single time I listen to the tracks mentioned above. It surprises me so much that while I cannot listen to certain types of music even once leave alone repeating my listening experience, the kind of music that Jai Uttal, Krishna Das and others produce, I can listen for a lifetime and experience that joy again and again.
summary: How can I express my joy?

reviewText: excellent map for trail use, detailed and waterproof.  folds up well and the detail for the trails is good. only draw back is you will still need the forest service map to get the detail
Very high quality product.  Contains lots of useful information besides the map for camping in the Pecos.  A must have for any backpacking or hunting trip.
Just what was needed for our 1st backpacking trek in the Pecos. Love the quality and durability of this waterproof map.
I  bought this for my son and he said it seemed very durable and weatherproof. He liked it a lot.

It was good but not all the trails were listed. We met a couple in the parking lot and they said it took about an hour and 45 min to get to lake stewart, well they took a trail that was closed, we didn't know this at the time. We did take that trail down 3 days later. The waterproof was great and we did find out it poured all the way down the mountain. It was very helpful.

Kirtan is becoming increasingly popular in the U.S.  As more people embrace a yogic lifestyle, it is only natural that eventually they will find their way to kirtan. If you are unfamiliar with kirtan, it is based on the concept of 'bhakti yoga' - the yoga of devotion. Singing the names of gods or goddesses in a call and response style with hypnotic Indian music in the background, kirtan is believed to bring a deep connection with the divinity within all of us.Jai Uttal's The Art and Practice of Ecstatic Chant delivers the whole mood of kirtan beautifully.  A devotee of kirtan since the age of 19, this talented musician has put together a CD that is melodic, sensuous, intense and truly uplifting.  You cannot help but feel moved when the first note hits your ears.  There is over 2 hours of music in this CD - and never once will you feel bored.  Uttal has a gorgeous voice - you can feel his love of kirtan in every syllable that he utters.There is an introduction in the CD, where Uttal explains kirtan and the path that led him to it.  This is a great piece - I feel that it gives an insight from a true devotee.  The intro helps even those who are new to kirtan to understand the significance and beauty of this ancient and spiritual art.  I recommend this highly to everyone - not just those on the yogic journey.There are a few kirtan 'stars' out there in the US these days - Krishna Das and Ragani to name a few - who are helping a wide audience enjoy and appreciate kirtan. While they are wonderful in their own right, my personal favorite will always be Jai Uttal.
Great water-proof map with clear delineation and trail guides.  Not extremely detailed but just right if you want a basic topo.
The map was very well done. It helped a lot.It was very large so I photocopied the part I needed. Wish I had done it on waterproof paper.

This map is great if you are looking for detail of the area between lake Tahoe and Yosemite, and east into nevada.. I like the fact that it has the different types of land marked on it (color coded).. ie: natnl forest, BLM land, Indian land, state land, etc... the scale (1:126,720) is good as an overview, but i might want something w/ more resolution for hiking / backpacking.  It also does a pretty good job of (accurately) labeling all those numbered remote national forest roads.  It is fairly large, and therefore a bit unwieldy, but the paper seems like it will hold up to many un/re-foldings.one complaint i have is that the coordinates are only in the deg, min, sec format.  I personally prefer the UTM coord system, especially for use w/ my GPS.Great for:-4x4 enthusiasts-rock hounds-those wanting to explore some of these lesser known / more remote areas
Good quality. Waterproof. Clear. I would prefer several smaller maps with more detail. I haven't yet hiked with it, so I am not sure how it will do. It's certainly good enough as an overview.
summary: Nice Map - a little too large

reviewText: Yes, this map is huge. But it also has a lot of fine detail. I just end up folding it into the area I need and slip it in a zip top bag for extra protection. Its surface is waxy and repels water. I even ended up using it as a makeshift rain cover on a day hike during a downpour. A must have for anyone venturing into the Trinity Alps!
summary: Best map of the Trinity Alps

reviewText: Not really worth the money. Call the Shawnee National Forest ranger station and they e-mail you a much more detailed map for $3

This actually wasn't a map of the Malheur National Forest but a map of the Southern Blue Mountains of Oregon.  It included the National Forest in great detail so it was more than I paid for.  The delivery was very quick and I wouldn't hesitate to do business with the seller again.
Different paced "songs" make this CD interesting. Useful for meditation, as the chants are repetitive. Great for yoga and breathwork.
Excellent map of the forest, a must if you'll be driving around on your own looking for camping spots and love super-detailed maps.

From the first cut I couldn't help dancing. Such joy!  The intro to Kirtan was perfect, simple and helpful.  It helped me to "see" the music from my heart.  This music inspires my devotion to the Gods and Goddesses of my belief system.  I know that Jai Uttal has been given a gift and he shares it with us beatuifully.  Not only is his voice majickal but the instruments carry me to places in the world I've never seen, but feel homesick for.  ~Namaste~
I am a map freak and use them all the time , while a little pricey this map is great for our grouse hunting and locating roads , trails and hunting areas.
Just what I needed, planning on a trip to Prince Of Wales to go fishing this fall, big birthday trip for me, never been to Alaska before, as close to Paradise as I will ever get.
Maps at your fingertips. This is a great product to check out areas that you want to visit and plan hiking and backpacking trips. It's really easy to print the maps that you need.

This music and chanting is the best Kirtan music I've heard for trance dancing.You can easily slip into a different level of consciousness with this one.The talking track is an explanation of Kirtan  and he explains it with clarity and devotion.He has an incredible voice.If your looking for a quiet reflective kirtan this is not the one ,you wont be able to keep your body still with the rythm of his music.EXCELLENT
summary: The Art and Practice of Ecstatic Chant

reviewText: Bought this from an outdoor shop in Prescott, AZ.  When you finally find the area you want, it takes a long time for the type of map to come up.  When you get the area you want to print and then select print, it takes a long time for it to do it.  Then you see what is on the print screen and it isn't anything like what you had on the screen before you asked it to print.  Neither the store where I bought it or AllTrails will agree to give me my money back.  I will not be paying for this next year.  A regular map will work better.
Great teaching and learning tool! Kids and parents enjoy playing and learning together.  Categories are easy to use. Lots of fun.

reviewerName: Pilot Mark in Arizona, USA "Pilot Mark"
reviewText: I had difficulty with the interface and product confusion. I had password problems when signing on, and the method for reset seemed troublesome at the time. I finally lost interest in pursuing what it might give me. I just used and relied on the website created by hikers in Arizona, which satisfied all the technical needs for the 14 overnight hikes I made in 2013.Part of the difficulty was the confusion between Trimble Mapping software and this product. The two companies were merging I believe, and one did not accept the other's sign on permissions... big hassle at the time with which maps were actually available to me and the related sign-on issues.I should have probably requested an extension to my subscription once the companies seemed to iron out their wrinkles, but it was all pretty confusing to me, even as I have extensive experience with computers... heck I built my flight simulator computer and it is equipped with 8 monitors!I never used the mapping paper provided in the kit because I never got to where I could get a backpacking route designed and ready for print. YUCK, the interface was confusing with the Trimble mess too. I wouldn't buy this product... seems Trimble Outdoors has the overriding product of the merger, I don't really know... never took the time to figure it out.
summary: Hardly used it in the year of my subscription

reviewText: This product hold great promise, but the execution is disappointing.  The ability to conveniently access topo, terrain, and Trails Illustrated maps from a single source sounds great.  Unfortunately the functionality compared to the older TOPO! product is poor.  Trip planning, route planning, compass, find, waypoint, etc. functions are either very primitive or missing altogether.When attempting to print maps from my MAC and HP printer, I literally only get half a map.  The bottom half of the image doesn't print, and what does print is of low quality.  I recently discovered that National Geo no longer supports MAC users on TOPO and suspect the same poor service support caries over to the new product.This is a good idea that needs to be fully baked.  Hopefully National Geo and Alltrails will fix these issues and make the patches available to us unwitting beta testers!
summary: Not ready for prime time; MAC users beware

reviewText: The printing quality of the sleeves is sub par and the sleeves are wider and longer than standard sleeves. Was not impressed.
Wish they would of written a better description on these sleeves. They don't tell you how many you get (50) and that they do not fit well with mtg cards.
My sign language students love to play Sign Language Bingo and looking at the fun cards to learn and review
great buy

The set includes a DVD, a book, and a yoga ball that measures 26 in. or 66 cm. The ball is a nice size for my height (5'5), and works perfectly for me. The DVDs provide fun, interactive workouts and allow me to monitor my progress by comparing techniques to those of the instructors. I've owned several of these throughout the years and have been quite pleased. Great product, Amazon!
summary: Great item! Free ball is a nice touch.

reviewText: I recently bought the Ultimate Outdoor Map Kit. I might be able to make the maps work...with some work. But as is unless it is on the very small list of detailed maps they have available I have to know where the trails are and put them in by hand. The printing quality was fairly decent. But for harder hikes I'll definitely buy the actual maps anyways and for easy hikes just use the free maps they hand out to everyone. The information I found on alltrails was generally wrong. I understand this is a mostly a user database and it is people adding the wrong information. When the length of the trail is listed as 1.4 miles and from personal experience and after two seconds of research I find that the trails actually measure over 7 miles according to the official website, it bums me out. Then I look and see that the locations are wrong. One trailhead was supposedly in the middle of a river. I tried adding photos and there were errors for 1/3 of them. I tried correcting trails and some of the information did make it through but not all of it and  I don't feel it's my job to fix things. I tried adding new trails that weren't there and they just disappear. So I can't even make myself a "accomplishment list". I guess the only thing I'll use this for is to get ideas for new trails that I can research somewhere else before I actually attempt them. Back to pushpins on the map for my done and wishlist trails. Overall a pretty big disappointment.
summary: Can I get my money back?

reviewText: I purchased this kit at Half Price Books--fabulous store btw.  However I agree with the other reviews...the ball is too small. And even though it does say 26 inch ball, when I measured it, it is NOT 26 inches.  It might be about 16 or 17 inches by my measurements, which is roughly 43 cm. That is close to the 45cm exercise ball, which is 2 sizes down from what should be in this box.  The store is letting me return it...I am 6ft tall and 160 lbs--this ball will not work :)  Get me an actual 26 inch ball and it might.This link might be helpful: [...]  So, if you fall in the 5ft and under range, this ball should work for you.Good luck!!

This set comes with lots of equipment including a well-detailed book, wide choice of video workouts (although they are boring, the exercises are quite effective,) and a terrific set of supplementary equipment. However, 3-in-one ball only comes in one size --26"-- which is way too small, and I am only 5'6". The video instructors use larger balls that fit them.I am quite disappointed and will have to return it to the store.

The set may be worth it for the equipment alone - the ball, band, and web all seem to be good quality. I bought this set from Sam's Club, and afterward found out on the publisher's website that the DVD is not intended for North America. *edit: the publisher's website references and ISBN different from mine - my version may indeed be intended for U.S. use* My home DVD player could not play any of the DVDs. My laptop managed to start one of them, but it could not play the other two because the disks are warped! Not sure if I'll be returning the set yet - I needed a ball anyway, and the additional equipment may be worth the overall price - but if you're looking for instruction (and especially if you live in the U.S.), best to look elsewhere. The book is 192 pages with full color photographs and looks like it has helpful information in it, but the binding does not allow it to lie flat and thus is difficult to use while exercising.
summary: good equipment, but watch out for the DVDs

reviewText: I bought this kit at Sam's Club for only $19.99 last week. I have used each of the five DVD's and find them fun, relaxing and effective. The DVD's have nice visual backgrounds and music. The DVD makes it easy to choose specific sections of each workout that you want to do or to select the entire workout. Warm ups at the beginning, and stretches at the end are included in each DVD. I couldn't get bored with exercise with this much variety in routines to choose from. The workouts don't seem hard when I am doing them, but I do have enough muscle soreness afterward to know that the muscles are getting worked. I recommend this kit to anyone who wants to work out at home, at their own pace and convenience.

I ordered this hoping that it would be a good alternative to running or biking.  The kit is amazing, I loved everything that came with it, however one DVD was scratched upon purchase and skipped regularly when I played it in my laptop.  Although the ball seems to be fully inflated when it is 17" in diameter, I was able to inflate it to about 21" but with some trouble (the instructions say that you can keep inflating it until it reaches 26", it just takes a while).  When putting the web on the ball to use the resistance bands, I found that they were ripped and had one snap in half when I was using it.  Not only that, but the ball is not good quality either. I enjoyed the workouts, but did not like the equipment and am planning on sending it back as soon as possible.
I love kits in general, and this was a great one. It comes with an exercise ball, pump and a great book. The Shipping was really fast & efficient.

It is a great system. I can use the dvd's at home and when I go to work with my clients and want to change things up. I just take my book with me and flip the pages. I love that the book is a spiral binder book, the pages stay open and doesn't close shut like other books you buy. How does anyone expect to use a workout book if the pages do not lay flat? Great concept and keep them coming.
All the cards were there an in very good shape.

I was excited to get so much for such a small amount of money...then I received the kit and started to use it.  The DVDs are not actual work outs, they are basic how-to videos...which is great if you are just starting out with any of these types of workouts, but not so great if you have done them and want a video you can use to get an actual workout with.  The only DVD that taught me anything was the Tai Chi one.  But, again, disappointment abounds.  The moves were shown with the teaches facing to the front.  Perhaps there are people that can watch the screen and reverse the moves without having to turn their backs to the screen and crane their necks backwards over their shoulder to try and keep up....but I am not one of those people.  I have books that do a better job.  On the other hand, the videos are shot well, with lots of great tips, and step-by-step how-tos for safe practice of many of these, so you decide if these videos match your level of experience.....
Its really cute but too small! my daughter loves it but i think it would last a day, play and just leave it
this map and its companion (west) are the best maps that you will find of moab. period.buy them.

The presentation is very nice, but i did not expect that it was that short, specielly the pencils. The notebook and the drawers are beautiful, but the pencils are really short and are not very good. It is hard to color with them, they are very clear
This came in on time and I am veru happy with it, I haved used it already and it makes taking out the pins in my glock 32 very easy

Best maps in the business for Moab and surrounding areas.  Make sure you get EAST and WEST maps even if you only plan on being on one side of town (Arches National Park, for instance).  A few trails span both maps and you'll be happy you had both if your trail does.Great maps that hold up over many years.  If you are going mountain biking in the Moab area and haven't updated your map in a few years, make sure you get the most recent addition.  There are so many amazing new trails that have just been built in the past few years that you'll want to have a map for.  Otherwise, do what my friends and I do and pair up and buy one map each.  That way you'll spend less and you'll essentially have both maps to explore with.Have fun!

I had a factory Glock tool that I was using for my Glock 26, 27, and 17.  I've since lost it and had needed another.  Since I've used Ghost products prior, and know that they are reliable, I had decided to order this one.  Sure enough, this is just as good as a factory tool.
summary: Works as well as the factory tool

reviewText: These are great maps with a lot of detail.  Only issue - I had trouble determining the trail type and direction in the really 'busy' parts of the map.  A detail window with greater scale would have solved the problem.  Rode for 3 days around Moab and never got lost.  Trail rating system is for 4x4 which really is not right for a dirt bike.  You will need the East and West Moab Maps to get info on all of the trails.  Epic rides...you will enjoy this.
summary: Best I have found - could be a little better

reviewText: This works no better than any 3/32 punch you would find at the hardware store. Actually, I think you would be better with a regular punch as it has more to hold on to.
summary: It's a punch with a Glock logo.

reviewText: I purchased this thinking maybe I need a special tool to easily pop off my base plates for my magazines, but it does the same as a regular punch tool. Glock mags are a pain to get the base plates off.  The tool does not really make a difference.
summary: Ok,tool does what a regular punch does.

reviewText: This Ghost Inc armorers tool, as far as I can tell, is just like the factory Glock tool, can't beat the price for the quality.  This one tool is a must for Glock owners!
its a glock tool - not much to say. everyone should have one in the gear bag if you own a glock(s).easy purchase, fast shipping, no issues.
If u don't have it .. Get it. All you need to completely take down your glock. Any model any gen.

Needed this tool to really break down my G22, and it works perfectly for that. No difference from OEM I suspect.However, had an added bonus when realizing that I needed a punch to properly disassemble the bolt carrier in my AR for a thorough cleaning, and this tool worked perfectly to push the carrier's retaining pin out and then back into place after the job was completed. Excellent! It is now in my range bag for safe keeping.
summary: Glock punch tool - needed for your Glock and other applications too

reviewText: If you don't have a 3/32 punch or would like to have one in your Glock bag, this is okay.  The butt end of it is handy for pushing pins back in place.  If you already have a 3/32 punch and don't need another, don't both with this one.
Accurate and durable... the map was easy to read and looked new after 9 days in the Winds. Was also compact and easy to close.
summary: got me exactly where i wanted to be

reviewText: I bought 2 of these as gifts: one for a hiker and one for a fisherman. Both were very excited to get them and both eagerly started going through them as soon as they could. From what I gathered as I looked through them, the book offers good, detailed maps for northeast NY areas of hiking and fishing. Can't say more until I know they are actually put to use but the outlook seems positive.
my boyfriend ordered this for himself for christmas and he loooooooooves it! i couldnt be more happy! this was perfect

Learn the tradition! Not only an instructional video, but a living document designed to preserve a cultural tradition, the Yang Style Long Form, as passed down from Yang, Pan-Hou (of the original Yang Family Lineage)! But do not be fooled! This is not some archaic relic of a bygone age. It is a living, vital art! Practice of this form will bring you a healthy and relaxed body, a clear mind, and a strong sense of martial intent! This Taijiquan form, unlike so many others, has not lost its martial arts essense.For easier learning, the form has been broken down into three parts, allowing you to learn the Taiji Form in a seamless flow. Included as well is the Taiji Qigong set which is essential for a deep understanding of the internal side of Taijiquan. This video will aid you on your way to achieving a true mind/body synthesis! Complements the book Taijiquan, Classical Yang Style.Develop a healthy body and a clear mind!Learn to feel and direct your Qi!Learn the correct breathing patterns to match the movements of the form!Split screen for convenient viewing from different angles!

I bought this guide because I'm planning an end-to-end this summer and generally like to over-plan things. I found this book very helpful and especially liked the specific details about where it may be hard to find water. The book was concise and I found it pleasant to read as well.
I've had mine for more than a year. The carabiner easily clips on to purse, pack, or belt loop; it's cute; it's bright. A handy flashlight when you need one!

I got sick of digging in my bag for my keys so I bought one of these, strung the keychain on it and now I just clip it to the ring on my bag. When I'm ready to go, I just snag the keys off the purse, hit the light and it's quick and easy. I must have a dozen of these around. The light is not a beacon but it's bright enough to get around with and that's all I need.
I got this as a stocking stuffer for my fly fishing husband.  It is perfect for a quick reference guide when tying those pesky knots!

I always get these when I dive a site where the cards are available. I have around 220 dives logged, many wreck dives, and no matter how good the viz is, is's hard to take in a complete picture of a ship a hundred feet down. So before a dive, these cards are a great way to orient yourself with the site, and afterwards they make a fantastc souvenir. They are well made, very detailed and very tough. Highly recommended!
These pocket guides are everything they said they would be.  Great quick ref guide a compact for my vest pocket.
It is set up for beginners and will be very helpful to them. It's not a bad reference for the more experienced fisherman either. I really liked the tab feature for quick reference.
As a former diver, I only recently discovered that this U-Boat was sunk off the coast and even better that you can dive on it!

I have used several different guides , however this one is by far the best. It's arranged in a logical concise manner , and it's waterproof as well. I won't head to my favorite trout stream without it.
summary: A must for your tackle box

reviewText: The video is rather long but does a good job providing the basic knowledge and equipment familiarity required for beginning tree climbers.  Geared primarily to recreational climbing, the basics also apply to the beginning arborist.  The information is presented clearly with closeups that make the knots and climbing techniques easy to learn and apply.
I bought this newspaper for my son for Christmas. Heis a Boston RedSox Fan. He is very happy with the material.I made the right choice buying this gift.
summary: Boston Red Sox Greatest Moments Newspaper

reviewText: My husband had this watch for years, lost it, and I've looked all over for one to replace it.  It was his favorite!  I found a replacement on Amazon.  Thank you Amazon!!

Fantastic product that is a must have for any life long Giants fan.  Although I'm still a kid, it's great looking over these articles with my dad and grandpa to look back at the greatest moments in Giants history.
You can only buy so many baseball hats, beer coozies and replica helmets for 'Skins fans. This is a unique gift that is personal and edifying for the football fan on your list.
summary: Makes great gift for Redskins fan!

reviewText: Great gift for any dolphins fanTons of fin facta and cool illustrations.. was meant as a stocking stuffer and turned into one of his favorite gifts.
I bought this for my boyfriend who is a huge NY Rangers fan! He absolutely loved this gift and I highly recommend this as a gift for anyone who loves the NY Rangers!
I used this type of device from my friend and that time I like this so I bought from here. Not used this perticuler one but I am sure this will work.

After looking through the book when I received it, I was happy with my purchase!  The pictures are fun!  Finding the masked rider has different levels of difficulty.  The pictures are a little rough, but for a 5 year old, it will be a good challenge for him. I almost don't want to give the book away for a Christmas present!

We plan on using it to weigh our baby for our home birth. The cost was VERY reasonable. Even though the packaging and instructions are written in Manadrin (Or Cantonese), the scale works readily out of the box and is very easy to figure out.It will have many other practical purposes for us beyond weighing a newborn child
summary: Nice and small, plus it works

reviewText: Simple, accurate and value for money. Does the job well. Easy to handle and sturdy. Dispatched quickly and arrived in good condition.

This device was fast and easy to install, it took me maybe a couple minutes at most and it was all set. The normal light is also very easy to see and has a nice set of various functions (solid, flash, random light flash) to meet personal preference.  The laser lines also can be solid or blinking as well which is great to have the extra option.Pros:Low costEasy InstallationMultiple light modes for both lightsGreat visibilityCons:I have a mounting area on the back of my bike that made it tricky to space it right for the lane laser not to hit it, I would of liked being able to shift the laser aims out wider to make up for this.  Instead I just mounted it a little higher and was fine as long as I don't have a bag on the back.

reviewText: I received this as a gift a couple of holiday seasons' back, and overall it's definitely a nice addition to any Red Sox fan's library. Since this 2012 edition pre-dates the latest championship, this edition obviously lacks anything having to do with the 2013 title.One of the hardest things to tell about this before buying it is just what's included. Of the 13 pages pictured on the product's cover (the ones included with this listing), 10 are in the 1975 to 2011 era (just 29 of the 64 pages, 63 pages if you discount the cover). The others (two on Ted Williams plus one from the 1915 Series) don't give a good representation of the majority of the content (the other 35 pages).Arguably, one of the most fun aspects of this is hunting for why some of the earlier pages were included. This treasure hunt reveals gems in Red Sox (and world) history which even a fairly decent fan like myself might not know (the diehards will probably be searching for the articles by date!). If you want to know what you are getting, keep reading. If you want to discover these gems for yourself, then stop reading - "spoilers" follow....The entire "paper" is split into four sections. The first (20 pages) covers 1904-1920 including a box score mention of Cy Young's perfect game, the first in baseball's "modern era" (according to Wikipedia), the first game played at Fenway Park, the 1912 pennant, Snodgrass's muff (which won the Sox the 7-game 1912 Series...in 8 games), and the 1915, 1916, and 1918 championships. Part of what is so wonderful about the articles from this time period is that the Sox's opponents for many of these key games were against New York-based rivals (Yankees, Brooklyn Dodgers). Consequently, these articles were big local news, not just big sports news, and are sandwiched on the Times front page between such monumental world headlines as "War Declared; Battle Raging in the Balkans" and "(Col. Theodore) Roosevelt Gains, Bullet Located, Lodged in Rib." Part 1, naturally, ends with the 1920 headline, "Ruth bought by New York Americans for $125,000."Part 2 (another 20 pages) covers the relatively quiet years from 1939 to 1975, very heavily loaded with Ted Williams highlights ("first big leaguer to bat in 100 runs," his All-Star game-winning HR, his 0.4057 batting average, and the change in his draft status from 1A to 3A, the homer that won the 1946 AL pennant, an AL MVP mention, another batting title, his 500th homer, and his final at-bat). It also includes mentions of Jimmy Foxx's 500th career homer and Lefty Grove's 300th victory.Part 2 continues with a 1967 piece on Bill Rohr's rookie debut game - a one-hitter. This page also includes this amusing description of batting gloves: "When Yankee Stadium opened in 1923....players and spectators then would have been flabbergasted at the idea of batters wearing golf gloves, and Ruth's comments might have been unprintable. Today, it is commonplace equipment, and several players on each team wear them to reduce blisters and other shocks" which nicely captures the changes in the times (from 1923 to 1967 to present where pretty much everyone wears them) and the Babe's infamously colorful personality in one fell swoop.This is followed by coverage of the 1967 pennant, Yaz's signing, Jim Lonborg's Cy Young victory, and the 1975 pennant.  Part 2 ends and Part 3 (16 pages) begins on a high note, with the Sox tied in Game 6 of the 1975 Series. Part 3 mercifully skips the next few weeks and fast-forwards to Fred Lynn's record setting MVP (first AL rookie to be named MVP). The other highlights in the following grim years for the Sox include Yaz's 3000th hit and retirement, the Rocket's 20-K game, the '86 pennant, and (painfully, for those of us who remember this Series well), coverage of Game 7 vs the Mets. :/ Ugh. `Nuff said.This section continues with coverage of the 1990 Division title, Roger Clemens's third Cy Young, Pedro's 1999 All-Star classic (which includes a photo of Ted Williams, who threw out the first pitch, and includes historically interesting coverage of Pete Rose's presence on the All-Century ballot, and of day one of Lance Armstrong's first Tour de France defense...also noteworth: the caption on Pedro's pic notes that "his victims included Sammy Sosa and Mark McGwire." Part 3 thematically ends with Ted Williams' obituary and several long retrospectives on his career and impact, and with the 2003 Division series title (featuring the massive outfield Collision between Johnny Damon and Damian Jackson).The last few pages of Part 3 begin the chronicle of the 2004 journey (stuck in this section, presumably, because the pages need to be grouped in 4s). The story begins with Game 6 of the ALCS  featuring the famed A-Rod pansy slap at Bronson Arroyo, and Curt Schilling's famed bloody sock. The first page of Part 4 (8 pages) features Tek jumping into Alan Embree's arms after the victory over the Yankees and includes another page including articles on the "Yankee mercenaries" and the "Monumental Collapse." Mark Bellhorn's clanger of Pesky's Pole in the 2004 Series gets a mention and then it skips ahead to the good part where Sox fans can "Kiss That Curse Goodbye: After 86 Years, Boston Gives the Boot To the Bambino."The 2007 coverage includes just Schilling's Game 1 victory in the World Seriews, and the subsequent "Coronation." The final pages include (oddly) Johnny Damon (as a Yankee)'s first visit to the DL (after over 10 years in the Majors), Wakefield's 2009 All-Star debut after 17 seasons, and last, in what must have seemed like a good idea at the time, an article on Bobby Valentine.I hope if the NYT updates this to include the 2013 title that they'll pitch the coverage of the 1986 Series finale and remove the article on Valentine (really - if they're going to include a manager article, it should be on Terry Francona, not Valentine or John Farrell) and should, in my opinion, include (much) more on the epic 2004 Yankees/Sox series. Some key highlights that I would want to see include the Idiots and their Why Not Us shirts, Dave Roberts's steal, Papi's Game 4 and 5 walk-offs, or even the Wakefield's heroics in the Game fiasco of a loss or the massive Duck parade that followed. Sure, the subsequent titles were/are great (yeah, call me spoiled), but the 2004 Championship will always be the one that broke the curse - and for that reason, to me, warrants more coverage.
summary: Many gems in Sox history from 1904 to 2012 - great selections overall, though would prefer more coverage of 2004

reviewText: Does everything it says it will do. I would like it so that the "lane" markings were a bit brighter on the ground. This does add a bit of safety to riding in the dark, as long as the motorists pay attention.

This tail light is bright and clearly visible from afar. The two lane laser is a pretty cool feature too. You have to adjust the height of the light to make the lasers line up correctly with the bike. For $10 it is a great tail light for bikes!

The light looks and feels cheap, the brightness appears to be good at this time. Did not like the way it looks so I am going to put it on my four-yr old granddaughters bicycle. She is happy to have it.

reviewText: Mounting can be tricky.  The laser "lanes" cant in or out depending on declination of the light and there's usually interference between the rider's feet and the lasers.  The lasers definitely burn through the batteries a little quicker.However, this is still unique enough that drivers will notice you just because they see something novel (even if they don't like the idea of bicyclists carving out their own lane).It's sad we've reached the point where we need flashing laser lines to be seen, but hey, we should have started paying attention to just how jaded the average cager is when the auto insurance industry made the middle tail light mandatory.
summary: Uniquely novel enough to get noticed by cagers, but needs to be mounted well and uses batteries more quickly

reviewText: Excellent light. Very safe . Very bright easy to install.  People keep asking where they can purchase one. I said Amazon.

reviewText: I have yet to install it because i like to use it when i walk at night.i keep it in my hand and turn it on when a car comes by, it has 3 different modes several blink and then the laser. not sure why there are 2 lines shinning down on the floor? but the pic is wrong the lines are and can be parallel to the bike, it all depends on what angle the light is mounted onto the seat bar.

Had one ride on the light! Mounted on my cross bike but rode it on the road. The laser worked well. Didn't spend any time adjusting for laser lines on each side of the bike like some have said in their reviews, It's simple unless you have a small bike. The laser lines are only seen when you come up about 10 feet from the bike, It's just there for the cool factor I believe. People riding next to you or a few feet behind can see the red laser lines very well. I believe the laser beams are not going to make cars more aware of the distance they need from you but it might help if they are approaching slowly.The LED light is plenty bright, just gotta make sure you aim it correctly when viewing from the rear. I do not know the run time since I only had one ride so far, but I assume it will be normal for LED lights. I'll try to come back and edit review (if I can) after a lot more rides.<edit> I've had 4 rides on it now and still holding good charge. Works great

reviewText: Bought as birthday present for 6 year old grandson, who immediately saw the possibilities and learned to balance and spin.  But, 3 and 7 year old granddaughters immediately claimed turns at either spinning standing and/or sitting. Time will tell it's longevity as a favored activity.

I bought this for my 4 yr old daughter to help her develop a better sense of balance. She loves to stand on it while playing wii games. I feel less guilty when she's getting screen time, b/c her balance is improving and she's getting a core workout as well. I'm not much of a skater, so I didn't get much out of this item on dry land. However, this thing is awesome on the snow. The poor-man's snowboard. I suggest getting the larger version as it will come in handy on the slopes.
The children love it.  It was a gift for my 2 of my grandsons ages 4 and 6.  My daughter-in-law has since purchased more for their friends birthdays.
Don't buy - my kids hated them and we have triplets so this was a huge waste of money. Dangerous too.

All 3 of my boys use this in our basement.  It works well on carpet and hard wood.  It is OK on ceramic tile.  I was afraid it would scratch the hardwood, but it has not.  My oldest is almost 200 pounds, and he is still able to move it around.
The neck is easy to manipulate into the right position, but it is also easy knock out of position.Not recommended for anyone who typically experiences a bumpy ride while riding.

This toy/sled is the biggest piece of garbage! It has been hyped on U-tube and it's really not worth a crap for anything! To start with I'm a father of 2 active and sports oriented kids, a son who's 10 and a daughter who's 9. To get an idea of our outside activities we ski, snowboard and go sledding every year and both children play hockey, baseball and basketball and we live in a middle class suburb of Chicago. This year we went to upper MI were my kids and their friends stay outside for hours going down hills on saucer sleds (which from our testing of all the other sleds are the absolute best). All of the 6 kids with us, ages 7-10, tried these for about 2 minutes and said they suck! The spooner's would go about 4 feet and then just stop and the kids said they tilted to the side and they couldn't stay on. As for using these during the summer if you've got a bike, basketball court, baseball field or a park field around you why waste any time tooling around on this thing? In the summer my son and daughter ride a ripstick waveboard and skateboards and these are infinitely more fun than this spooner piece of crap. As a final note what a piece of garbage this thing is: Since Christmas when my kids and their friends got these they have been sitting in a pile outside my garage and have not been touched once, the kids have absolutely no interest in these.
This is fun to try! Definitely works the core muscles and balance skills. The children are challenged by the activity but are alos very interested in improving their skills.
This is a great add on to my bike I can see what is behind me and see my baby in the seat on the back of the bike

This mirror is not a good choice for any bike. I used it on my own bike and couldn't see anything as the extension is too short to provide an image behind me. Also, it is very flimsy and the road vibrations will move the position of the mirror. To adjust it while biking, will create hazard. If I could give it no star, I would have. Do not buy this item.Durable Bicycle Bike Handlebar Rear View Mirror Super Light

Can't see a damn thing.  It is a 1:1 ratio so everything is too big.  It vibrates with the bike and doesn't show anything.  Buy something else... something that reduces the field of sight, wide angle in other words.  Back to the drawing board :(
summary: Not a good mirror (unless you are standing still).

reviewText: And I'm just going to offer my support for just an amazing time piece.  Not only it this watch attractive to look at, the combination of it's light weight performance, features including solar powered interface, and rugged design, make this time piece a cut above.  I love my PRG60T, and I'm waiting to see what they come up with for the next generation.

reviewText: Es un maravilla de reloj, un poco grande en tamaño, pero esta padrisimo. El extensible es muy comodo y tiene opcion de ajustar el tamaño aun sin quitar eslabones del reloj. llevo mas de un año con el y ningun problema. Aunque tiene muchas funciones que no son imprescindibles en un reloj, debo de reconocer que nunca esta de mas una brujula por que siempre la ocupas cuando menos lo imaginas.

Bigger than my Timex watch, but not as heavy. Easy to use. Excellent price. Auto light is great. Compass, altimeter, barometer, and thermometer work just fine. This watch is technological state of the art. Check it out!

I have the watch for 3 years now, and am very satisfied. It was quite a challenge though to get the 'lunitidal interval' value needed to display the correct tidal data. The manual lists the required numbers for several cities around the world, but tidal dynamics are extremely complicated and tides can differ several hours even when you go up north or south of the same coast. What made it more complicated, was that I am living in a country where English is not the main language, and I had no idea what I was looking for in local terms. Finally, I understood that lunitidal interval is known here as "gemiddeld havengetal" (Dutch), but still it was a real challenge to find it for the spot of coast I was planning to use the watch. It was not on the internet - ultimaltely I was able to find it in a specialized yearly nautical publication. I can imagine that not being able to find the right data, might let some users down. Casio should have realized this and should have put more effort into guiding the user to the right values. It might be the reason Casio left this option out of the newer Sea-Patchfinder models. For users in The Netherlands: I have uploaded a table at [...]As far as the watch: one problem I have with it, is that it does not have dual time, which I really need. Second, I do not understand why Casio has chosen not to print a complete 360 degree scale around the watch, but chose to print COMP, BARO and START in between the 210 and 330 degree values instead. Especially since it is also shown near the buttons as well as on the display at about the same spot. OK, it is nice to have a compass and a barometre, but don't need to read THREE times every time I look at my watch. Another disadvantage is that it is impossible to verify that the watch is level when using the compass. Especially at sea, this is essential. The watch does have some sort of tilt sensor to automatically switch on the light when you look at your wrist - it would have been nice if this feature had been used to indicate if the watch was level.A small disadvantage is the short lighting period. Having so many batteries aboard, this period could have been longer than 1.5 seconds. Also, it would have been nice if the moon graph was inverted - with the positive display showing the lighted part of the moon. Standing outside in the dark and pressing the light switch, results in seeing the dark part of the moon lighted up on your watch... Also, a button lock would have been nice. Because of its size, it is easy to press a button by mistake. Especially the Baro-button is prone to be pressed inadvertially when bending your wrist, supporting yourself during an activity.Otherwise, a perfect watch, which is extremely light for its size. The distinct beep when you return to time mode, is very handy. The glass does not scratch, it is perfectly protected by the bezel ring. I am looking for a replacement after 3 years, since the black plastic light switch broke off (it is only supported at the back by a small metal pin which is off-center, so pressing it eventually makes the connection snap) and the barometric pressure sensor went offline recently. Since I really need dual time and I do not like the newer Pathfinder model using about 1/4 of the display telling me about the battery status (what a waste of space!), I decided to compromise the tidal data and buy a Suunto watch (with button lock and sensor that indicates if the compass is level) next.
summary: Tidal data not that easy to adjustl

reviewText: I like it. I am happy, that I have schungite and can do a water, which make my skin younger and make me feel well.

this is an amazing watch its like having my own weather station on my wrist and its tought.its also quite entertaining using it while mountain biking. the only reason i gave it 4 stars is the sound of the alarm its not that loud that sometimes i can't hear it. considering the size of it its amazingly light. so thats how titanium feels like. and amazon.com/digitalwrist delivery is reliable got the watch within 2 working days.

reviewText: I've had mine since it was released in ~2006.  The battery meter still shows high and I've never replaced the battery thanks to the solar charging face.  I disagree with the other reviewer on the compass problem. Mine works very well but does need recalibration every several months if you need it to be perfect.  The altimeter is very close to perfect. Maybe off by 20-50ft but its a watch for crying out loud. I do enjoy the barometer for double checking my airplane when the field doesn't report pressure. I've loved it and its still ticking strong.

I was really excited to receive the Shungit stones and use them in our water. Once I got the bag, I rinsed them under the water because they were turning my fingers black and I thought maybe they were dirty. But then, as I washed them, I noticed the black came completely off some of the stones and underneath was just a common rock. And I found a few pieces of wood painted black and shaped like shards of rock as well. I'm very disappointed in the seller and product.

I purchased this pop up tent for me and my girlfriends  to use when we  tailgate!  Women do not like to use port- o-johns so this was the perfect answer to our problem!  its lightweight and folds up in literally 3 seconds - its great! :)
summary: Lightweight and serves my purpose perfectly!

reviewText: This was the best price on the web. Order was received quickly and packaged well. The instructions that were included were easy to follow.To the person that said the black was rubbing off . . . yes even if the stones are thoroughly rinsed and dried if you grab them they will make your hand black. When they are prepared and used properly they do not make the water black or show any color at all.The taste is wonderful. I have even used a few stones  for my cats and dogs water.The amounts that were sent are generous and will last a long time.I am so happy I found this product on Amazon.
Heavy enough to stay weighted down but light enough not to be overheated. just enough room inside.I would buy another one.
It did not come with any instructions, so I have not been able to fold it up again and have no idea who makes it.  Not Recommended
summary: The tent is not very durable

reviewText: Once this shelter is erect, it is not to horrible, however the zippers are way to tight and we have only used it on one rafting trip and the zippers seem like they will break each time you try to zip up.  putting it back in the carry bag is also a huge pain as there are no directions and you have to figure out how to fold. - Why can't tent manufactures make structures that give a tiny bit more room for zipping and bags that are actually large enough that you can put it away properly???
the winter was really hard on my 2yr old! until this showed up! now if he starts climbing the walls, i ask him to do 10 grasshoppers and it calm right down! love love this!
summary: every mother with a high needs kid needs this!
