I have tried several other resistance bands.  All of them broke.  I am about a month in of almost daily use and, so far, these have not broken or snapped.  They have nice grips and the resistance advertised seems to be accurate for each band.  I would like to emphasize to all who might read this that you have to wear eye protection when using resistance bands.  I wasn't wearing eye protection when my first set (of another brand) broke.  The band snapped back and hit on the side of my face very close to my eye.

These bands are good for everyone and at a reasonable price. I use them 3-4 times a week. They take up no room at all compared to all the free weights you would need to cover the same range of weight. Great product!!
summary: Good bands for beginners and experienced

reviewText: Bought these bands for the girlfriend as a Christmas present and I have to say these bands are well worth the price.  Each band has its own handles and are exactly as pictured.  My only concern is that the bulges that hold the bands to the handles are not very big and the door attachment stop is small so in order for it to work your door must have very little clearance between it and the floor.  Overall I am more than satisfied with my purchase at the moment and after a few more uses of these bands I will review how durable or not durable they are.  Enjoy!
summary: Great set of resistance bands! Exactly as pictured!

reviewText: These bands are great! The price is great! Super resistant and well made! The only bad thing is that my ferret chewed the yellow one, so I will have to buy a new one. :)

These bands are great. They have yet to fray or snap and the quality of the rubber leaves me to believe they will not snap for a long time or ever. The handles are nice and padded and the carrying bag fits everything in a small space. I would buy these again.

What can I say, these bands are great....so far. I've only owned them for about two weeks now, and they're holding up NICELY! They seem to work perfect for P90X, no problems whatsoever. If your having trouble trying to find resistance bands that wont come up short or snap on you, These seem to be the real deal, and for only 16 bucks, its most definitely a STEAL!
summary: BMP = Best Material Possible, or Black Mountain Products, whatever

reviewText: I got these bands to do with my P90X since I lost all the equipment in a move. They are far better quality than any other bands I've gotten as part of kit. Thick tubing, durable handles, and a decent carrying case for all! And the mix and match bands are perfect for altering the intensity for different exercises. This was well worth the money, I don't feel like I sacrificed quality for price AT ALL! Will definitely purchase from BMP again.
excellent, works to perfection. I can work out very wellRecomiendo a cualquiera a comprarloMuy buen articuloLo pueden pedir
Totally str8 like this product BMP ...workout with it after a carbo workout. It's a great workoutband ...I'll recommend this ..gotta get it
summary: Totally str8 like this product BMP

reviewText: The Bands are wonderful, and the resistance that they provide is great. The design is also really cool allowing the use of multiple bands and variable weights. They're much easier to use than light free weights. The only down side I saw thus far is with the directions. It took me a few minutes to figure out how to insert the bands into the grips. Mostly considering the thicker bands take a bit of effort to get in and out so I thought I was doing something wrong. But it's pretty intuitive and it just took a moment of thought. The other issue (small issue) i ran into was the suggested exercise pictures. They're a bit tough to understand in some cases and the wording and pictures can be a bit unclear. Overall great product though and I would totally recommend. Any real issues in types of exercises can be overcome with a quick Google search.They have amazing customer support and are really friendly. They honestly want you to have a wonderful product and stand behind their work 100%.I would recommend these bands and the company to anyone.
summary: Great Bands - Amazing Product - Amazing Customer Support

reviewText: Right from the first use I could tell that this was a serious product that was built to last. It is without a doubt the best resistance band style product I have seen thus far.

These bands are very high quality.  I love the fact that you can use up to 3 bands at a time for as much or as little resistance as desired.  The handles are soft and comfortable. They seem as though they will last a long time.  If not BMP has you covered with awesome customer service.  I enjoyed my first workout with these and look forward to many more.  I prefer these to weights.

I searched for a while to pick perfect bands which hive you the best workout with heaviest resistance reading review after review.I settled on this company because of the different variety of bands plus the ease of switching bands to get different weights.As I do P90x I can switch bands quickly and not lose too much time from time from my workout.Highly recommended for a great P90X workout.
summary: Best bang for your buck for P90X

reviewText: I purchased these resistance bands specifically to use with the Power 90 workout system and eventually with the P90X.  I'm not sure whether it's because I'm not used to resistance bands or they just can't replace free weights.For some exercises like the military press or anything that requires pulling the resistance bands above one's head, there is too much tension on my neck and shoulders.  I feel really uncomfortable using these bands for those exercises and feel like they could break.  It could be that the bands are too short for such exercises and longer bands may be better.  By the way, I'm only 5'3".It's not that I can't lift pull these bands over my head, because I lift comparable free weights without the tension on my neck and shoulders.  I sense that I'll sustain an injury, if I were to keep using these bands for those exercises.Also, the plastic handles brushes against my hand while pulling above my head as well.  I recommend the set with the other handles that you can also attach multiple bands to.  But the handle for this set is ok too, if you don't do exercises that requires pulling these bands above your head.The only reason I may not return these bands is because I'm saving to use them for modified pull-ups and for travel.  Other than that, although I bought these since they're cheaper than free weights, I'm going to have to end up buying free weights anyway.

I purchased two Black Mountian resistance bands sets. I like the soft handles and their flexability because they allow me to combine anywhere from 1 to all 5 bands for max. resistance. I would like to recommend that the loop on the door anchor to be made just a little larger so that one can slide the handles thru it while the bands are still attached. The bands  and handles appear to be of good quality, well made and will hold up if used properly.  I'am more than satisied with my purchase.

This set of bands is top quality.  It is easy to interchange bands for varying weight/pull combinations.  The handles are comfortable and appear to be well made.  I agree with other reviews that the door anchor could be larger to accommodate easier use, but since I have another anchor which is larger, it is not an issue with me.Did have one small problem with the carrying case, but I called Black Mountain and talked to Rick.  He took care of it immediately.  I am most pleased with the purchase.

This product is awesome, and at a great deal.  You can add up to three bands on each handle, which can total to approximately 60 pounds of resistance.  And the product is quite durable.When I first got the product, it took a minute to figure out how to get the bands into the handles as no instructions were provided for this (pinch the band and slide it into the handle).So far, the bands have held up and I have yet to notice any tearing.
I have been using my Saber Bands regularly for almost a week now, and I can tell that they are excellent quality bands, highly recommended!!!
summary: My Saber Bands are excellent quality bands, highly recommended!!!

reviewText: This are fantastic!!Each to change the tubes. Weight is are very challenging. Sturdy material. Provides great resistance. Love using the green tubing its 10-12 pounds. The Red color is 30 pounds so its good for people who workout a lot or for men who love stronger resistance.

The bands are solid and the bar is very sturdy. The bar is wider than most, so it fits well across wider doorways than others I've tried. The rubber on the bars is sturdy and durable, too. Great products!

I was very impressed with this set. Most of the resistance bands in the campus gym are fixed to a specific handle - you can't compound them to increase the resistance. With these bands, though, it's easy to create precisely the correct amount of resistance by mixing combinations from just a few bands. The handles are also surprisingly comfortable - more than I thought they'd be. The bands themselves also seem very durable and unlikely to age quickly.The door anchor is sufficient for its purpose, though you do have to physically remove the handles from the bands in order to slide it on and off (of course, this is better than having the "clipping mechanism" some door anchors use, which almost invariably wear out and break). If you use the door anchor for pull-downs, though, you're probably using a lot more weight than you would for other exercises, so switching in and out of "door mode" usually requires removing the handles to change the bands anyway. Still, if the loop in the anchor were wide enough to pull the handle through, the issue would be averted entirely.I don't usually use bands over weights, but I wanted to try them mostly as a travel-friendly alternative. They certainly fit that purpose well, especially with the bag which they give you. All together, they don't take up much room in a suitcase, and even then it's unlikely that you'd need to take all five bands with you anyway.There was one small issue, however. The blue band had a few small spots of green rubber fused to the side (almost like the raised edge of a plastic figure that was cast in a mold - a sort of continuation of the rubber that didn't fit the rest of the figure). When I mentioned this to customer service, they profusely apologized and promised to send a replacement immediately. I can't say I mind, though - the band works just fine, and you wouldn't have noticed unless you were looking for that one spot.
This is a great product! It arrived right on time and packaging was great. Can't wait to start working out.

When I received this product, it did not come with the little wrench to construct it, nor did it come with an instruction manual or adequate bolts. The bolts are too long for the product so that when you try to tighten the one end, the bolt just spins around. It did not come with any washers to tighten the bolts. There are many other pull-up bars on Amazon. Buy one of those instead.

The packaging was perfect. The Shipping was super fast. The instructions for the Chin up Bar was super easy and everything needed to build it ( nails ) came with it. The resistance bands are nice and come with a manual of strength levels. Cute Bag for storing the bands. Simply the best ever. ! recommend them to anyone that wants a good work out at home, without paying to much !
summary: Chin Up Bar and Resistance Bands

The band handle started to fray, granted I was using all the band at the same time, so I sent an e-mail to Black Mountain Product and they sent me out a new handle within a week. Great customer service. I highly recommend this product, you can work out anywhere.

reviewText: It was exactly what we were looking for. Built very strong and sturdy. It was a big hit at our expo!

This Carnival Wheel is okay, but not as good as I had hoped for. If you screw the bolt of the wheel tightly against the backboard, the spinning wheel comes to an abrupt halt after you spin it, instead of slowly rolling to a gradual stop like the wheels you see at carnivals. That takes away the fun and excitement of participants who would otherwise watch the wheel slowing down as they hope it stops on their prize (or number). Conversely, if you screw the bolt in too loose the wheel becomes all wobbly, causing it to bang against the backboard and affecting the turning of the wheel so that it's spin seems unnatural, the last thing you want in a game with any kind of prizes where people might wonder if it's somehow rigged. The dry-erase surface is a bit odd and hard to make look professional when you're just using dry-erse markers unless you have perfect handwriting. The manufacturer says to email them if you want to find out where to get pre-fitted word documents that you can customize, but I emailed them and didn't get a reply. I don't see how cut up word documents would fit on the wheel without tape or glue so I didn't pursue it. And yes it's relatively easy to assemble even without instructions, but for this kind of money the least they should do is include some type of written directions so you wouldn't have to do it by trial and error. Also, one of the four corner pads on the bottom of the base was missing, so I took the other three off to make it level. Overall it seems sturdy but even so, it is way overpriced. In my opinion it shouldn't sell for a penny more thn $25.00

This prize wheel was a big hit at conventions.  Very sturdy and works great.  We must have spun about 300 in a two day weekend without flaw.  Very happy with this item.  Shipping was really fast, we were afraid that it would not get to us on time for the convention.  We bought it on Sunday and received it by Thursday.  That's what I call fast shipping.  Thanks for everything.

This kit has everything you need to convert your bike into an electric assist. Only a few minor issues. I took one star off for no liner installed for the tire rim. This is important as some of the rough edges were not fully sanded down where the spoke holes were drilled. Easy to fix before inflating the inner tube. Battery bag is just the right size for large capacity 12v SLA. I went with an 18AH model. Battery bag could be improved with the addition of a carrying strap to make taking the bag indoors easier given the weight of SLA batteries for charging purposes and protecting from temperature extremes or theft. The battery power lines are not labeled as indicated in the instruction manual. There was a warning in the book that the warranty would be invalidated if user hooked up wrong. Since the wires aren't labeled I could hardly see how the end user would be at fault if one did mix up the polarity as there is no real way to test which is which. Fortunately one of the lines is fused which is typically placed on the positive line making it easier to identify.

The promise was 5 star. Upon opening the box, found that it did not include the battery. I called the company and they stated that it was NOT included. I thought I could deal with that, unt I found the battery to power a thousand watt motor was double the purchase price of the motor, over $600. After reading the meager instructions with bare wires to connect to battery, I decided to give up, mail it back and take the $50 mailing cost as a lesson learned on mail order items

"All right, Marines, listen up!" -- I'm here to tell you that if you've ever wanted a pulse rifle, now is the time to grab your trenching shovel and break open the piggy bank. Like many ardent fans, I've wanted a pulse rifle ever since seeing the movie Aliens. I'm also an avid gamer, and in such obvious favorites as Alien Trilogy, Alien vs. Predator for the Atari Jaguar, and Aliens vs. Predator for the PC, the pulse rifle is the standby weapon, making actually owning one that much sweeter.Until recently, the only commercially available pulse rifles have been the Icons resin replica for over half a grand, or various moving-part offerings from a few small production companies in the thousand-dollar-plus range. Considering what you'd pay for just a chunk of resin with some paint thrown at it, the Matrix AEG Pulse Rifle is a ridiculous bargain, all the way around. Actual working parts? Check. Real metal construction? Check. Authentic firearm weight and heft? Fully functional LCD ammo counter? Actually SHOOTS?! Check, check, and check! This gun looks fantastic, has actual moving and functional parts to play with, and is a blast to shoot. As an avid Aliens fan, I'm extremely pleased with my purchase."That's the grenade launcher; I don't think you want to mess with that." -- Unfortunately, this product is not perfect. The first gripes are about authenticity. There is a shotgun shell instead of a grenade in the under-barrel pump assembly. It's not visible unless you slide the pump grip back, but it's not authentic. Also, "Made in China" is printed conspicuously on the side of the gun, instead of one of the dozen less obvious places it could have gone. It would have been nice if the magazine was incorporated into the magazine cap. The orange barrel caps are required by law in many places. If it's legal to bypass this requirement (check local laws), I recommend painting over rather than removing them. They're securely glued on, and I have yet to see a photo of a clean removal job online. There are other minor authenticity complaints, but for how good this product looks for the price, your best bet would be to buy it and make your own modifications if you really feel the need. I'm very happy with mine, "as is".The other gripes regard quality control, and they are mostly legitimate. You will need a better battery. I ended up exchanging my first pulse rifle because of a bad battery and broken LCD counter switch, right out of the box. The battery in my second unit was good, but not strong enough to cycle the piston until it was loosened up first by a higher amperage battery. You will also want to buy a "smart" charger, as these batteries are notoriously easy to overcharge--thus killing them. The edges of the retractable stock will scratch down to bare metal after only a few slides back and forth. The magazine is a real pain to line up correctly and insert (though internal shimming might help this). Other reported problems include scratches, cracks in the plastic, and loose internal screws. While there have been complaints about the shroud (carrying handle) being flimsy and breaking, I think that this could occur during run-and-gun games, but not during normal target shooting and handling. Others have reported loose pistol grips and pump action slides, and I did notice that both of these were tighter on the replacement pulse rifle I ended up with (but were acceptable on the first gun). I don't believe I've ever purchased a product with so many known issues (though not all justified), and I specifically bought from Amazon rather than cheaper vendors elsewhere in case I needed an exchange. Good thing I did, too, and the vendor (Access Store) was absolutely outstanding in quickly handling the return in the most convenient way possible, at no cost to me."Remember--short, controlled bursts." -- Most of the other reviews I've read have been by individuals that bought this first as a pulse rifle collectible, and second as an Airsoft gun. I'm in the same category, although I have experience with traditional airguns and firearms. If you're just looking for an Airsoft rifle for games or target shooting, you can find more reliable and easier to use products for less, elsewhere. In particular, the pulse rifle handles awkwardly compared to more traditional firearms, has no built in sights, and the magazine is hard to line up right and swap out. However, as a pulse rifle collectible that also actually shoots, this gun is a blast. Aiming down the groove in the carrying handle is not very precise and takes some getting used to, though the large groove does afford a good view of your BBs streaking away toward the target. I had no firing problems in either single or full auto mode. Velocity is reportedly good for an Airsoft rifle (close to 400 fps), and after some target shooting (the accuracy is reasonable for an Airsoft rifle), had fun shredding some aluminum cans.IMPORTANT NOTES:--Even with a higher amperage battery, my gun's piston would not cycle until I switched it to full auto. I had no sticking problems in either mode after that. Once the piston was apparently un-stuck, the included stock battery could power it--but not before. Again, you will need a better battery--and a smart charger. The manual provides no charging instructions whatsoever, but if you stick with the stock parts, figure the charging time in hours by dividing the mA (milliamps) of the battery by the output of the charger (1100 mA battery divided by 350 mA charger output = 3.1 hours for a full charge, for what was included with mine).--The manual is terrible, unless you're already used to brown-box Chinese products that come with little or no product information. I've literally seen more thorough product instructions on bubble gum. In case you're wondering why it continually warns against disassembling your gun, while showing you in detail exactly how to take it completely apart, it's because this manual originally came with a parts kit that you could use to modify a Thompson M1A1 Airsoft gun into a pulse rifle. (The parts kit alone originally sold for more than the complete rifle here, again making this quite the bargain.)--Note that the magazine capacity is actually 190 rounds, not the 60 or 70 listed (the manual can't even agree with itself). Also, in case you're new to Airsoft, you fill a high capacity magazine by pouring BBs through the small pop-open hatch on the top, and then fully wind the geared wheel on the bottom of the magazine until it starts making a different clicking sound--this usually takes about half a minute or so. You don't use a "charging rod" to load the included clip as the manual confusingly states. This may be obvious to experienced shooters, but for a first-time purchaser the manual again fails miserably.--Use only seamless, high quality 6mm BBs. There are several available weights, and the manufacturer recommends 0.23g BBs. This will prevent jamming, feeding and other ammo problems."Marines, we are leaving!" -- In conclusion, despite some possible issues, the Matrix AEG Pulse Rifle is an Aliens fan's dream, at a very reasonable price. I had to get an exchange to end up with a perfect unit (which is why I dock one star), but I still consider it well worth the trouble. I will probably only shoot mine on an occasional basis, and display it the rest of the time, but even if it never fires another shot, this particular Aliens fan is extremely pleased with his purchase.UPDATE -- I recently purchased a chronograph and wanted to drop some velocity figures in here. Running about 80 rounds (0.23 g Goldenball) through a Shooting Chrony Beta Master gave me an average of 351 fps with a 1600 mA battery, with no statistically significant difference between the stock 1100 mA battery (though firing rate was clearly slower in the latter) or between single shot and full auto modes; overall variation for all my tests was only around 3 fps. This velocity is close to what I would expect, considering that the advertised velocity was undoubtedly obtained with a lighter BB (which you want to avoid to prevent possible jams).

reviewText: When I first got this gun I liked it and it shot pretty good for a 16 dollar gun. the first thing that i noticed was that the secondary safety trigger didnt work and the semi-full auto switch would change on its own while shooting. it wasnt that big of a deal because I just got this to shoot in my backyard for fun. Then about 2 days later, the gun broke. I tried to shoot it and i heard a snap and all the gear would do is stall and the batteries would overheat in like 5 minutes, making the whole gun hot. All of the internals except half of the barrel is plastic and cheap plastic at that. I took it apart to see what happened and the internals were just shattered. I do NOT reccomend this gun to anyone. A spring gun from walmart is more reliable

In general:- Awesome replica!(But a few QC issues and damages)- Bullet counter works- Performs well- 9.6v or higher battery recommended for this gearbox- Pseudo-shotgun instead of grenade launcher, but still looks great- High priced but good buyer protection- Evike take-down manual included- Probably not so durable in the field, but sufficient - don't lose your mag plate!- For playing airsoft in comfort: not ideal- For playing airsoft looking like a BA colonial marine: ideal- Kills bugs deadIn detail:When I found out this airsoft gun existed, I had to have it. I've been a fan of the movie "Aliens" ever since it came out and my dad brought me to watch it in the theater. I was about 7 or 8 years old. Yeah, I nearly crapped my pants, but eventually loved the movie and the whole franchise, to include "Predator", "Aliens vs. Predator" and all the other movies and even comic books. Even today, with flicks like "Prometheus", the story continues to unfold and has almost become its own genre.This replica is a nice homage to that...and its a limited edition (although also available from Snow Wolf, see below), so what to do next is obvious for any die-hard fan of the Aliens franchise, or airsoft player who's also a fan. I no longer play airsoft, but I still had to have one of these. I found it on sale later somewhere else, but I'm happy with Amazon's service and I'm glad I went this route. Amazon's, and the seller's, buyer protection/returns policies are great. Turns out, I needed it.Because it is Chinese-made, I expected a few quality control issues. This is called a "custom" replica made by Matrix (under Evike), but I believe this is the exact same Pulse Rifle made by Snow Wolf, who makes decent AEG's even though they are a Chinese company. This is (probably) just the re-branded Matrix version. The bad reputation China has had for quality control is slowly but steadily moving out the door, and some of the best items are from there. Some of the Chinese airsoft brands are actually pretty great in quality, along with the Taiwanese brands. That being said, I still don't trust Chinese brands I don't have experience with, like this one.So when I first received it, I was hugely disappointed and there were some issues I just could not accept since this was intended as a collectible. The seller was extremely helpful though, and replaced it for free. After a few very helpful emails from them and putting it right back in the box it came in, it was in the mail.The issues were what someone who intends to use this for airsoft games would consider "minor". But for a collector, they were hard to ignore. It may have been shipping damage, since the gun ships with almost no padding at all, but it seemed more like quality control issues. The upper black receiver had a few small scratches in weird places under the stock but they were down to the bare metal. I'm fine with that if I was the one making all the scratches, but this is supposed to be brand new. The pump for the mock grenade launcher was very "loose" and didn't stay shut, but that wasn't that big of a deal. The pistol grip felt loose and the plastic creaked if you picked it up by the grip. It was covered in white or yellow dust and to top it all off, a small black Phillips screw fell out of the mag well as soon as I opened it. I heard it rattling around before I even opened the box...but it wasn't just a BB, like I hoped. I wasn't sure if all of them came like this from the factory, but the seller agreed to send another just in case. (THANK YOU AGAIN!)That loose screw could've been nothing, or left-over from the factory, but it could also be something pretty important. Like off of the gear box or other internals. I just put it back in the magwell and packed it all up immediately, deciding not to take a chance. If I was going to run around playing airsoft in the woods with it, I probably wouldn't care...but I have a G&G; F2000 if I ever felt like doing that. As a collectors item, I want my pulse rifle to be as close to perfect as possible, and have everything attached.The second Pulse Rifle arrived:...in a lot better condition! But now I can see that they all have quality control issues. Some, more than others. This one looked fine though, and even felt a little more solid for some reason. The shotgun pump also stayed in place.Dust, still there but not as much. It must be from the factory, machining or packaging process. C'mon, Snow Wolf...invest in a vacuum cleaner?Scratches, not on the metal but on the plastic this time, but not too noticeable. As if someone took a car key and tossed it a few times at the gun. A few bigger gouges/scuffs...probably shipping damage. I can look past it. Its nothing you'd notice unless you were holding it up and inspecting it in sunlight.Overall, it looks a lot better and could pass for "new". I'm happy with the condition. There are no bright scratches on the metal parts. No loose screws! It even feels more solid and the shotgun pump stays put, although that part wasn't a big deal.Function - I'm not going to chrono this or give any field reports because that's all been done in many other reviews. To sum it up, this gun performs great on the field, if you intend it for that. It's based on the Marui Thompson. But I can also say...It needs a battery and smart charger - Definitely use a 9.6v battery (or more if you can fit it with modifications) and skip the 8.4v. The metal v6 gearbox should be able to handle it. The rate of fire is lower than I hoped for with a 8.4v 1600mah Tenergy battery. I don't even bother using the included battery. It's next to useless and they probably include it with the gun just for looks. A Pulse Rifle should sound like its "pulsing", not "pop pop pop". The good news is that any AEG is upgradable, and the 9.6v battery alone will make a difference...but for the true "tinkerers" out there, you can use a li-po battery for extreme rate of fire. Just learn li-po safety first, because they can explode, burn out your trigger, or catch on fire if mishandled...Appearance - Aside from the quality control issues, the gun itself is somewhat solidly constructed, and for a fan of Aliens, looks AMAZING! Except for the "Made in China" stamped on the side, but 100mph tape or paint could fix that. Not too much wobbles or creaks on the gun, except the grip. On the second gun I received, the grip seems tighter. This is something you can probably tighten yourself, but I don't expect wobbly grips right out of the box. This is a very front-heavy gun though, and the added stress can't help. But it's not too heavy overall or too unwieldy of a gun, even if its not even close to being balanced. But I am used to an 8-9lb F2000. This weighs a lot less of course, but it's no M4 carbine. The Pulse Rifle is not designed for comfort, it's designed for a movie set, and you don't use one for ergonomics. You use it for killin xeno's!Upgradeable - There's lots of info out there on possible mods for this gun. You could try installing an actual working airsoft grenade launcher or shotgun up front. Not to mention all the internal upgrades you can do, if inclined. To use a li-po, you should at least install a fuse or MOSFET. If you want to remove the orange tips, if its legal in your area, its going to be tough. You'll need a heat gun because they're glued on. Probably easier to just paint them black. Some also paint the grenade launcher portion to make it look more realistic. But then again, it's fine just the way it is.The bottom line is that it's now possible for any hobbyists out there to get their hands on this fine piece of memorabilia, stick it on a wall or something, plink soda cans in the back yard, or play some airsoft games at the local field....and it won't break the bank. I've seen them in other colors too, on other sites...tan and woodland camo. But this olive drab version is more true to the films. A long time ago, only the über-SCI-fi-fans had replicas and they were usually really expensive, made of resin or other non-metal material, and did nothing at all. Airsoft kits came out later, but weren't affordable or easy to find, either.This is a limited edition, according to Matrix. You could try getting the Snow Wolf version from another seller, maybe direct from HK or China. But, it will probably cost more, and be exactly the same...just maybe not the colors. If you're a fan of Aliens, enough to think that having a working (airsoft) Pulse Rifle around your house would be the COOLEST THING EVER...or if you're an airsoft player that wants to have something really different from everyone else...well then you'd better get one before they stop making them and they go up in price. Who cares about quality control issues?

What a real piece of crud.  Broke after two days of using.  The curved maghazine breaks open when loading and pieces pop out.  With shipping paid about $25- save a little more and get a CO2 crossman c11- well worth the extra 15 bucks or so.

I love using toe socks with fivefingered shoes. I'd rather wash my shoes because of visible dirt than because of funky smells. These socks have a nice silky feel to them, and it's very easy to "scoot" your toes up into your shoes. I have noticed, though, that the Fila socks weave doesn't have as much all around stretch as the Injinji socks. My little toes are stubborn, and the Injinji socks make it easier to get those last little piggies into the sock. The Fila socks can end up snug on one side of your toe, especially right after a shower. Just an observation I've made after a few months of comparing the two brands. The thickness of the Fila socks is perfect. Not so thick as to impede your comfort, and not so thin that your foot slides around in the shoe. The "no-show" sock does show on the top of your foot, but the heel stays in place perfectly. I've never had the back of the sock slip down.

I will start by saying that I did not expect very much for the cheap price that I paid for this hatchet, so I can easily say that it is better than I expected.  I have developed an interest in wood carving with a hatchet or axe and I am planning to buy a much more expensive carving hatchet if my interest continues.  I bought this Bahco to test my interest and see if it would be sustained long enough to justify buying the one that I really want which cost about nine times as much as the Bahco.It holds a cutting edge as good as any cheap hardware store grade axe that I have ever owned, but it did take about 15 minutes with a grinder, file and diamond hone to get it shaped and sharpened the first time.The one gripe that I do have with it is the shape of the handle.  The handle seems to be too thin and does not fit my hand very comfortably.  I will probably make a new handle that I like better and while I have the head off of the handle, I will sand down some of square edges and corners on the head.  The handle is decent quality but it just does not fit my hand.

The head is well made although not at all sharp. It will take a lot of work to profile it to a sharp edge. The handle leaves a lot to be desired and it will not be easy to find one to fit for a replacement. More like a club with a poor handle. The grain in the handle is cross instead of vertical and it is a little warped. May as well buy a cheap box store hatchet with a steel or fiberglass handle and save your money.
we are happy with this purchase.  Car has nice detail.  My son calls him Fast "talking" Jack...no idea where he picked that up, but makes the whole family laugh.
The steel is not heat treated and with use the steel will buckle and divot. Please watch the review made from wranglerstar on YouTube before any purchase from this company.

When I received this axe, I went to my backyard, and chopped down an old fig tree. The next day, I removed the stump. This little axe works fine.Unfortunately, the bit needs to be redone after every use. The handle is very smooth and comfortable. No sheath.Wish I could give it five stars, but the steel is too soft.

Shhhhhhhhhhh.....there are not a lot of quality products that come from Germany at this great of a price. While building in Germany I used to use these Bahco hatchets for setting timber rafters and splitting kindling for Granny. There is not another hatchet being sold on Amazon that is of this quality in this price range. I brought two back to the USA in my luggage. Damn it! Can't do that any more.The metal has a very distinctive ring to it when chopping. The nice contoured radius edge is easy to maintain and sharpens up well with a few passes of a file. On the hatchets that I own the handles appear to be made of a tight grain beech. The hatchet overall tends to be a tad head heavy which I prefer for splitting wood. Let the tool do the work. I would say that these Bahco hatchets are lifetime tools. As in - they will last you your lifetime.Not really suited to be used as a belt hatchet and does not come with a sheath.Act now and buy two Bahco hatchets before those German wholesalers figure out that they can get more for this product.I've used mine for over 20 years and have only replaced the handle once.Don't waste your money on Fiskars and the China made hatchets.
Works fine just as advertised. folds flat and seems to be very strong.  Easy to install and not in the way.
Mounted this excellent little scope on my new ARMSCOR's MIG 22, in 22LR cal. & it zeroed in perfect & it looks great on myrifle. Love the Red/Green mil-dot retical w/OA ring.
I am impressed by the quality of this product and the convenience ...Thanks a lot and manufacturer to the sender ....
summary: Thanks a lot and manufacturer to the sender ....

Looks exactly as described! Just got mine today can't wait to try it out! For a $22.00 axe it looks and feels awesome. I will note, I can choke up all the way, and the handle feels good all around. The bare edge is coated with what I'm guessing is enamel. The head on mine is also stamped. It also comes with a little rubber blade cover that I think I'll hang onto to make a sheath with, and yes the wedge does have a loop or hanger, I think I'll cut mine off like Bensoutdoor since its broke anyways.***UPDATEThere are about two or three things you need to know before you buy this. 1. I bought this hatchet knowing it will break. Its a tool, its 20 dollars, and its not going to compete with the best in the industry. Why? you would be loosing money producing a tool and only charging $20 apiece from the time it takes to make a top notch tool... pretty cut and dry here...2. the paint on the handle will apparently blister your hand (according to old jimbo, axe expert), either stand, rub, scrape it off, get blisters, or wrap the handle3. Uh last but not least buy a $20 dollar tool expecting to own a tool worth $20... it won't hold and edge here lets be realistic people. For a reference please see wranglerstar's video 'Bahco axe update' on youtube, I didn't watch the whole thing, no offence, to anyone! I Don't have the time to watch his videos, I work 60 hours a week...  I bought this knowing what it is and plan on its ultimate destruction followed by a full refurbish. So my advice if you want an axe under 20$... don't. either buy a used head that you did some homework on, on ebay (I'm currently biding on many that have flushed in lately),or if you got the cash and, well there's no one stopping you, buy a nice one like a Roselli, a gransfors bruks, uhm... wetterlings...I would recommend Snow and Nealley but their heads appear to be made in china, and hults bruks got pretty good reviews from oldjimboold jimbo told me also a friend's of his axe started to chip at the edge, he said to keep filing away at it and it would be fine and it was. I also saw a picture of a wetterlings that chipped from hitting a knot in a tree... and uhm, well don't do that, unless you want an $80+ axe to chip...** One more thing old jimbo told me, let your axe handle season for a bit before traveling to the mountains with it, or it might split apparently. axe handles should be dried already, but there's a difference between wood that's been seasoned for 1 year, and one that's been seasoned for 3, to 7 years...for a reference on that one please see the book hunting with bow and arrow(its public domain meaning its free to download, goggle hunting with bow and arrow PDF) chapter 5, paragraph 17. that may be for making a bow, but my point is still the same, wood changes in time and depending on the moisture content in the air.if you don't know where to start:do yourself a huge favor and do what I did, watch dave canterbury's '21st Century Longhunter Axes, Hawks, and the Nesmuk Double bit' video on youtubeonce again, did not watch the whole thing... don't have time, just listened to the axe names and said, 'that's interesting'...or you could goggle carving axethen switch to image view and scroll down...pick one you want and read a bit about itmy fav looking ones are from:holtheathwoodentreenoutdoors.magazine.free Scandinavian Bowl Carving*if you just goggle those you should come up seeing the same images I did, sorry, can't post links on here...well that's about all I know. Do your homework before you buy and don't be afraid to try something out, remember you only buy a rolex if you can afford 2... I would recommend custom maker's and their axe's... like a blacksmith's but without knowledge and reviews of their axe's or their process's, well your taking a gamble for their expertise... that they didn't mess it up. Some people may be irritated at me for posting this much knowledge on amazon, but the way I see it amazon reviewer's who know more than me have been helping save me money for, 7 years now... including alternative names, pros, cons, where to look, what to do, useful information, and I owe em one.

Really great product, sturdy construction and stays together even through heavy use. The colors are pure and the length is perfect. I clipped off the clip at the bottom and put a key ring through the bottom of the lanyard and it perfectly fits anything i need to put on there. feels very soft and snug when around your neck, and looks great hanging out of your pocket. Thanks to the seller, for an amazing product. Always gets people to the topic of your gt500 ;)

reviewText: The map is a fold out just under 10 inches long with a plastic cover and is 32 inches wide when fully oppened. On one side is the big scope showing the airport and city to the west.  On the back of the map is a breakdown of Central Kathmandu and a further breakdown on Thamel.  There is an index for book stores(must have paid for this, trekking business(same comment), travel companies (ditto) and finally hotels and guest houses.  These businesses use different symbols and colors.  One will also find places to eat and other businesses and points of interest but not indexed.I like to have a feel of a city because I walk around a lot.  Thamel is particularly difficult to navigate and this map and my compass came in handy more than once.  The scale of the map isn't always right on but there is enough detail to be able to locate a place and take it from there.  There are a lot of small streets and details that aren't included but you get a big picture.  I wouldn't go back to Kathmandu without the map.
summary: Came in handy more than once

reviewText: Having listened to the first four albums by Hackett, I was truly blown away. The ideas and musical genius of this man are stunning. I, being a follower of more melodic pop and classical, loved some of the soft, melodic ideas he came up with. 'Kim', 'The toast', 'Shadow of the hierophant', 'spectral mornings', to name a few melodic, soft masterpieces.Cured I could just about accept, it had 'Cradle of Swans' which harked back to his earlier work and the last track 'Turn Back time' was a very melodic piece with nice harmonies, the rest was ok.This is something of a culture shock for me. Gone are any soft songs and tuneful tracks with different instruments and multi layered songs. It is just rubbish pop song after rubbish pop song, and Hackett just sounds out of tune and there is just no interest to any of the tracks. I was really suffering by track 2. Boring, unispired pap.The only track with any merit whatsoever is 'India Rubber Man', and that's probably because it has a change in texture, noticeable to the rest of this crap.

I always like Steve Hackett's explorations. This album has a well-structured set list, the flow from song to song is very good. Cell 151 seems to be a tip of the hat to the disco machine, because of the insistent rhythm. My favorite is India Rubber Man.

Another great one, even better than Cured as far as pop writing, he relies more on his Guitar chops here to carry a lot of the tracks and thats a good thing. I've played this right after Genesis's wonderful ABACAB album and they sound very good back to back.

SON SEALSChicago FireAlligator ALCD4720Son Seals used to wake up and say, "Blues". He had an aggressive sound that was uniquely Chicago. This fierce CD has captured that sound and feel. Although the disc was recorded in 1980, it has a '70s funk/blues sound. The nine energy-laced songs feature seven originals by Seals, and two covers - the more notable one by Cropper and Pickett. Most songs are up-tempo with hearty girth. As on Midnight Son, Seal's mighty five-piece core band is enlarged by a full brass section with sax, trumpet, and trombone. Chicago Fire closely resembles Midnight Son which was recently chosen among the Top 200 greatest guitar recordings of all time by GuitarOne Magazine.Buzzard Luck highlights the difficulties and challenges faced by Seals upon arriving in Chicago. Tragic lyrics like ("I can't kill nothing and won't nothing die") paint a bleak picture. Flame-like horns musically drive the band and Seals, in particular, to extreme. I'm Not Tired is one of Seals most swinging numbers ever. Leaving Home contains an arrangement that Seals loved. It is also featured on Going Back Home from Midnight Son, and he used to use it on covers performed during his live sets. On the track, Seals' ferocious vocals are as haunting as King Solomon's bewitching organ. Landlord At My Door contains the definitive Son Seals sound that we now deeply miss. What is that sound? A deep, funk groove with lots of hefty blues layered on top pulsating horns with a guitar solo that effortlessly discharges notes and emotions. Like the disc's opening track, the song weighs the advantages and disadvantages of urban versus rural life. On Nobody Wants A Loser, Seals proclaims, ("the game of life is the hardest one to win"). When he was on top and ahead of that game, there was no stopping the Bad Axe man. By the time you get to hearing Watching Every Move You Make, you start thinking you have already heard the song. Although you haven't, this pinpoints the CD's greatest downfall. The songs are too similar.Seals' gruff vocals sound like your grouchy old uncle or grandfather. Just like them, there is something that welcomes you. On guitar, Son Seals was a precision shooter. You can hear it in every solo he fires on this 41-minute album. Although the sound quality isn't as bright as today's polished productions, and some instruments are too low in the mix, this genuine blues CD will have you falling in love with the blues, and Son Seals, all over again. They don't make greasy, working-class blues albums like this anymore.--- Tim Holek
summary: Fall In Love With The Blues Again

reviewText: This is a great album. Do you like electric guitar? Buy this CD. "Cell 151" was Steve's first bona fide single. And it is a great track. "Walking Through Walls" is a good cut, but I always thought it would have worked as an instrumental, too. Speaking of instrumentals, "Hackett To Pieces" is pure. If you're a guitarist and you think you've got chops, listen to that last track. And enjoy!

This is a really good album, it is more musically developed than Cured, although the latter is better ( just a bit! ). Buy this if you liked cured. I am 13 and i liked the trick of the tail ERA and i think the 2 'pop' hackett albums ( Highly' and Cured) are the best. I never liked the early stuff ( read my please don't touch review if you want a laugh!) but i did think that Spectral morning's was decent enough, although the early ones would have been improved if steve sung on them more ( i mean 'hoping our love will last'? it sounds like a supremes hit, not the writer of classics like 'air conditioned nightmare' and ' 11th earl of mar' from genesis.Go out and buy this if you liked cured, but if you think it is is going to be like the old, it isn't, although it is not as pop as cured. ( check out the intrumental on 'cell 151' with the 'Queen' brian may type guitar riff and the Abacab synth guitar).
So check this out... You're hopping up and down... You're listening to this album... DUDE... You're ROCKIN'!! C'mon, Ben Weasel likes this. check out the RC5.

In my search for a BW player I would like to emulate, I found someone whose style is my favorite. "Train like" left hand,"heart", the hands don't run over each other, tasteful, great"bluesy" right hand, Pure Boogie Woogie & blues from the "Boogie Boom" era. He's awesome!
Have other works by Becvar i.e. Forever Blue Sky and rate this alongside it as sound I resonate with. Worth a listen on the mini-clips provided by Amazon.
summary: Beautiful music to think, dream, work and live with...

reviewText: This composer has an excellent way of getting across his feeling. The music is very relaxing and is esoterically pleasing. It's also very helpful in healing methods

Musically this one continues in the direction Steve explored with the previos album, 'Cured', although here the somgs are more focussed and stronger than the previous effort. Part of this is due to having gone back to a band situation(featuring Nick Magnus and Marillion's Ian Mosely), while there's also a more 'progressive' element going as well. Highly Strung is also his last band/rock album with recurring themes and reprises, something which had charactarized some of his other earlier albums(Defector, Voyage Of The Acolyte) and also on such Genesis albums as Wind & Wuthering. The track sequence is different from the original vinyl, so I'll give it one star less, as the original sequence was more effective. Here's the rundown: Camino Royale - A stage favorite which remains in Hackett's live set to this day. Nice interplay between guitars & synthCell 151 - Great rock track with extended instrumental section at the end. I suppose this is very similar to his ex-bandmates' 'Abacab' song, in that it is a rock song with an extended jam starting halfway through the song.Always Somewhere Else - good instrumental which starts with a Hackett/Magnus guitar/acoustic piano duet which developes into an instrumental piece.Walking Through Walls - musically more in common with early 80's funk bands like Chic and Ray Parker JR. or 'You Dropped A Bomb On Me' than Genesis of old. A mild funk synth bass line dominates this, one of Steve's more offbeat yet accessable efforts.Give It Away - in contrast, this sounds very much like a lost GTR track, with its arena anthem-like guitar lines and vocals. Where was Max Bacon for these sessions? This could have been a hit- surely it does sound a bit like Asia, the most AOR track on the album. Nice one.Weightless - A song about Hang-gliding. Pleasant enough.Group Therapy - as the title of this track says, this jazzy instrumental is a great group effort, with Steve and Magnus trading off licks and the rhythm section providing a solid bed for them to go off.India Rubber Man - forgettable but short slow number which reprises the theme from 'Always Somewhere Else'.Hackett To Pieces - Another group number, this caps off Highly Strung rather nicely. In fact, with the heavy drumming, this also sounds like it could have been a Genesis number. Genesis could have performed this well, and would have had Steve remained with them.Solid playing, fine songs. If you're able to find it, do yourself a favor and pick it up, its one of my favorits.

When you like Jimmy Yancey, than you must hear Charlie Booty too. In my opion only 2 bluespianomen can play in that tradition: The first is Charlie, the second is Martin Pyrker from Austria. CB is the man who really feels the blues in his heart and his hands. After a stroke he had to learn bluespiano totally new and believe me, he is on the right track: No gimmicks, no unrolling stuff, he can give lessons to so many "too fast players" in the world of boogie woogie. It's not the so often heard typical white man's pimpy pianosound, it's bluespiano at it's best. Give him your ears, you'll love him!
summary: Charlie and Jimmy are the best!

reviewText: Although I have to say Quicksilver is coming in as my all time favorite group and although my favorite album of the 8 or 9 I have (don't remember right now) changes from month to month, this album stands out as an instrumental tour-de-force.  It's like the Beatles' playing on Abby Road -- that kind of perfection -- only you just know Quicksilver could walk out on a stage today and play this album live and it would be equally masterful.I love this group and love this album.
summary: Current Quicksilver Messenger Service favorite album

reviewText: At this point in their career, QMS were kinda stuck in second gear. The last 2 Lp's had done ok but not enough to warrant any big push from Crapitol, I mean Capitol Records. But Duncan, Valenti, et al responded by making this record. Jazzy , Folky and rocking all at the same time,for me this is the best QMS album. A big plus is that Bill Inglot did the remastering. QMS albums always suffered from crappy sound quality, but this remastered disc sounds great!!! I highly recommend this along with the next one (Comin' Thru)...........

reviewerName: Grateful Jerry "Dark Star -> The Other One"
reviewText: By late 1971 Quicksilver was Gary Duncan, Dino Valenti and Greg Elmore. The band added Mark Ryan on bass and Chuck Steaks on keyboards who had been doing stuff with Country Joe. In November of 1971, Quicksilver released Quicksilver which failed to make much of a dent with record buyers which is a shame. The album itself is pretty good although there are a couple of throw aways but I find all the Dino era Quicksilver albums have those. The band's sound has also somewhat changed as this line up of the band seems to be finding it's own musical style which works quite well. While this isn't the Quicksilver album that I'd start my collection with, it isn't one I'd miss either.
summary: Somewhere between three and four stars

reviewText: Quicksilver Messenger Service / Quicksilver:  This album proves once again that QMS could make an entertaining album without ever being able to reach that `classic' album level.  This album is a joy to listen to but it produced no hits (no radio airplay) and it ultimately led to QMS being dismissed as a band of the past (and when the radio heads of the early 1970's came to that conclusion, the total absence of airplay meant that you really were a band of the past).  This is a nice album, an enjoyable album, and a four star album.

I first heard Quicksilver Messenger Service in the late sixties and still prefer the original line-up of John Cippolina, Gary Duncan, David Frieberg and Greg Elmore. In my opinion, their best album was the live 'Happy Trails.'As personnel began to mutate in later albums and Dino Valenti began to control the group's direction, I liked them less and less. However, this 1971 offering is a gem. From the double-tracked lead guitars of the first song, 'Hope,' on through, the writing is masterful and the musicianship exquisite. Duncan proves himself a capable guitarist without the idiosyncratic Cippolina. Recommended.

as with all music that touches or speaks to us, it is the context of our lives at the time we were introduced as much as anything. this album synthesises my loves and rebellions from a space in time. nostalgia is not what it used to be. paul

It ain't "Happy Trails," and Cipollina, Freiberg, and Hopkins have all disappeared, but this is possibly the best of the Valenti-fronted QMS albums, in part because the band is really no longer pretending to be Quicksilver. It's Dino's show from first to last, with Duncan as sidekick, and some of the tunes ("Play My Guitar," "Song For Frisco") are as good as this team will produce. Of course, there's also some junk ("Out of My Mind," "Rebel"), but most of the songs fall comfortably in between.

This disc is a must for any lover of the continental boychoir sound! The sound is never strained like some, but not muffled as some of the English choirs tend to be. The performances are clear and tender, never forceful each one like a delicate piece of Meissen porcelain. The perfect CD to listen to with a glass of wine and your significant other on Christmas Eve....that is if you can't get to Dresden!
It was cheap, but I expected that. Figured for less than $20 I'd give it a try.  Not gonna work for anything over a couple pounds.

Coming so late in their career, this album was overlooked by almost everyone, fans and non-fans alike.  That's too bad, because it's one of their best.  Most people agree that the shining moment for this band was their first album, and they may be right.  But although this album sounded entirely different, it was another definite high point, and it's sad that almost nobody heard it.  "The Truth" is one of my all-time favorite QMS songs, right up there with "Fresh Air" (the closest they ever came to having a "hit" song), from the "Just For Love" album.  "Song For Frisco" is another favorite.  And "Fire Brothers" and "Don't Cry My Lady Love" are downright pretty.  Great stuff.  If you're already a fan and never bought this album, I would highly recommend it.  If you're not a fan and are just curious about this band, this really wouldn't be a bad place to start.  But while you're at it, pick up the first album, too.
summary: A fine album-- but nobody knew it.

reviewText: This album was the sixth by Quicksilver (Messenger Service). On first listen, it sounded like a non-event. The second side (from "Fire Brothers" to "The Truth") is, however, absolutely wonderful!  These four songs just flow. I hardly ever played the first side. Obviously,  I don't have the CD so I can't vouch for the sound - as it seems to have  been reissued in 1994 it should be good, though. The best QMS album for my  money is the first. I never got as excited as others over "Happy  Trails" (although the sleeve is fabulous!) and would have to say this  is my second favourite. They were almost a different band by this stage  (1971), of course, so don't expect instrumental fireworks. Recommended.
Am assembling jazz music for a slide presentation of our New Orleans trip in 2010. The Marsalis family of musicians is outstanding.

Jimmy Dawkins - Tribute To OrangeNo reviews on this yet so I will put this out there. This collection was recorded in the early 70's and pairs Jimmy with Gatemouth Brown on 9 cuts and Otis Rush on 4. As you can imagine when you have all of these guitar slingers on hand there will be some string bending going on and this was certainly the case here. Lots of stinging guitar on virtually every track. Dawkins handled the vocals and did a fine job. The songs are well crafted and mostly written by Dawkins. Sound quality is fine although the production seems to drop the band low in the mix a few times behind the guitars for short intervals. The liner notes do not detail who plays what solos so you will need to listen close to figure that out but it's all good stuff.Summary: quality modern electric blues with an emphasis on the guitar. Not a bum track in the bunch. Recommended!

reviewText: Once an unlucky candidate at the Eurosong contest (she got ... o point!), Monica Zetterlund by chance gained popularity in jazz, performing with the greatest musicians. A very fine singer, she is at ease as well with original jazz as with more unfamiliar Swedish jazz and her renditions in Swedish are very melodious. You ought to know this singer and consider her among the best jazz songbirds!

reviewText: From one of thre many 90's meetings of Lee Perry and British dj Mad Professor, this cd is a nice meeting of these 2 fertile minds.The results are pretty straight forward, (by Perry's standards) decent roots reggae. Perry's vocals dominate many of these tracks, and his voice is in fine form. The Dub Professor also sings some, which is an added bonus.While many other essential cds of Perry are around, this collection is a good one and showcases the meeting of 2 of dub music's great minds.

Unorthodox is a great death metal album of it's time. I recommend it to anyone who likes classic Swedish death metal (early entombed, etc.). See the beginnings of a musical genius, Dan Swano.

I did not know about Lake of Tears until I got Martin Popoff's Encyclopedia Of Heavy Metal in 1997. He gave it 10 out of 10 stars and I have to agree because there is not one bad song on this album. Each song has a cool groove, melodic lead guitar, good fantasy lyrics, and decent vocals. The moods created on some of the songs are fantastic! I would describe Lake Of Tears as slow to mid tempo metal with a bit of goth and a bit of Pink Floyd. They are one of the best undiscovered bands out there. Check out Forever Autumn and Black Brick road too!

After the EOS debut in '91 Nothing But Death Remains, which was more like a demo than a proper recording, EOS really found their trademark style with Unorthodox. If you are a fan of melodic death metal this album is a must. Some songs are kinda filler but overall great album. Don't waste your time with that "best of" album. Buy Unorthodox, Purgatory Afterglow and Crimson NOW!!!!
summary: Edge of Sanity hit their stride.

reviewText: Dan Swano, despite his success with the Purgatory Afterglow and Crimson albums with Edge of Sanity, has said many times that his favourite EOS album has always been Unorthodox. I guess I can see why. First of all, those who call Edge of Sanity a melodic Death Metal band are wrong. EOS has never been merely a 'melodic' Death band to begin with; it's just that they stressed melody and the structure of their songs had powerful hooks that grab listeners by their balls. If you go back to the roots of this amazing band, you'll discover that their first three albums are the epitome of old school Death Metal with a proggressive approach.Unorthodox is the 1992 release of EOS, but most of the songs were written between 1989 and 1991. The music presented on this record is very raw in style, crushingly heavy and incredibly powerful. All aspects of Death Metal are served here and they are also enhanced by proggy overtones (remember Dan Swano is one of the biggest progheads ever). Added to the mold of the songcraft are non-metal elements such as piano, keyboards, violin and even cello. Make no mistake though, none of these instruments are used to overpower, but they are utilised to add colour and texture as well as immense variety. As "Enigma" kicks off after the short instrumental track, we are faced with strangely accessible time signatures that continue to shift, change and redefine themselves. Right after Dan Swano's clean vocals (also the only clean vocals on the entire album) the intense rhythm work played by Sami Nerberg (and Dan Swano himself) abounds with so much energy that it is hard stay unresponsive to the magic that shines through. "Enigma" consists of three 'psalms', namely "The Blessing", "Celestial Dissension" and "The Loss of Hallowed Life". The cerebral lyrical theme is utilised in a call-and-response kind of vocal delivery and with each passing second the riff architecture is further developed. It finally explodes into a chaotic wall of sound. While I happen to like "Enigma" best on this record, the rest of songs are far from filler. On "In the Veins" and "Darker Than Black", Dan's vocals are particularly raw, but not as refined as they are on the later EOS albums. However these vocals seem to fit the music a lot better. Keep in mind that Dan Swano was only 18 when he recorded this album and his vocals are somewhat in the vein of the earliest Doom-Death bands: slow, tortured, yet heavily brutal!"Everlasting" sees the band experimenting with various textures and the busy interplay during the main passage is stunning. The song structures are tremendously unorthodox (as the title itself suggests) and way ahead of their time. It's a shame this band got overlooked amongst the metal fans. I could name at least 50 Death Metal bands that came ten years after EOS and became a lot more popular. Similarly "After Afterlife" is a direct, speedy piece on the non-melodic spectrum of the genre. This sounds like a musical incarnation of entropic nihilism. The rhythm guitar pattern once again destroys (there are plenty of awesome RIFFS to be found here!) and pleases. The slow, seeping atmosphere is built upon wild drumming and throbbing bass figures as Nerberg and Swano experiment with delicate macrohythms to create a tapestry around the composition. Unorthodox is no doubt a different animal. This isn't as progressive as Crimson or as melodic as Purgatory Afterglow, but it's EOS's testament to creativity and originality from way back, the year 1992.
