reviewText: I have a great deal of admiration for Lake of Tears singer/guitarist Daniel Brennare.  His band's songs, and Brennare's own instrumental and voice work, have much less of the virtuosity associated with this brand of "melodic death metal", but somehow Lake of Tears comes off sounding great, the simplicity a liberating influence which allows the band to focus on music and songs rather than need to dazzle.  By not struggling to impress, Lake of Tears does so mightily, at least to this listener.Sometimes it's hard to tell how seriously to take this music -- with titles like "Boogie Bubble", "Cosmic Weed" and "Devil's Diner", it's up for grabs.  But with a sound as good as this, who cares?  Brennare's rhythm work is great, heavy but not overwhelmingly dense, thus allowing for the top-end crunch so often missing from other distortion-happy metal guitarists.  Johan Oudhuis' drumming is also wonderful, simple and direct, creating a good clean groove for the songs, and Mikael Larsson's bass often contributes the anchoring hooks for the songs.  This band really knows how to make room for everybody, and the result is great-sounding recordings.The catchy bass intro to "Boogie Bubble" segues into a simple two-chord riff that carries the same pulsating metal groove as Metallica's best works; "The Four Strings of Mourning" is beautifully moody; "Lady Rosenred" has Brennare coupling vocals with clear-voiced Jennie Tebler to good effect, but with a bizarre double-time rhythm and disturbingly bare arrangement in the background; and "Raistlin and the Rose"'s mix of pastoral keyboard melodies and crunching power chords suggest Lake of Tears' later record, Forever Autumn.This is a band that makes a great argument against the de-tuning trend in metal these days.  So many bands are obsessed about playing lower and lower (even Metallica tunes down to C now), with seven-string and baritone guitars, that they forget Tony Iommi from Black Sabbath, the godfather of this style, used a treble booster to get his sound.  Most metal bands now aim so much for the bass that they forget the top-end punch; Lake of Tears, on the other hand, achieves its aggression without having to saturate every song with 20 tracks of growly guitars, using dynamics and space rather than block-headed density.  A Crimson Cosmos rocks harder than most records these days, and it has the potential to appeal to both fans of this "melodic metal" style as well as more mainstream listeners.
summary: Weird lyrics with great tunes and performances.

reviewText: Lake of Tears is a new band for me, although they've been around for a while. My wife has a bunch of metal compilation CDs and I was listening to one and it had "A Crimson Cosmos" on it. That song alone was enough to get me addicted!You've got to check out :When My Sun Comes DownDevil's DinerA Crimson CosmosBut not just this album! They've got others, check them out and I bet you'll agree. Nothing but joy when listening to Lake of Tears!I'm so sick of music today sounding like crap, like Ke$ha.. it seems like artists just want the mighty dollar and since the dollar isn't worth much anymore, neither do they feel their music must either. Ke$ha is crap! Buy Lake of Tears!
summary: Lake of Tears, more like Lake of Joy!

reviewText: Wow...this piece brings back so many memories. If you're familiar with the original Bang On Wax joint and many of the spinoff releases that followed the 1st 2 Bangin' On Wax projects then you'll know that Nini X is(rather was) none other than the homegirl Bloody Mary, one of my favorite Bangin' On Wax lyricists (and fine as she wannabe,too). This release was one of several that took the Bangin' On Wax thing to another level and baby girl rep's from start to finish(not for those with virgin ears cause you'll hear a "MF" every other bar...lol), only without puttin' the B in it or hoo bangin'. My personal favorite is "Jokin' Around" with Big Joker doin' vocals coupled with Nini's flowin' about the romance thing(identical to the Piru Love joint from Bangin' On Wax...so identical that if you listen close enough you can hear Lil Leak's shoutout from Bangin 1...lol). A keeper, especially for those into the 90's G style. If you're feelin' Nini...I also recommend Tweedy Bird Loc, Young Soldierz, and the Relativez to name a few. It's a shame baby girl is gone...Bloody Mary/Nini X,R.I.P.
summary: Memoy Lane: Nini X aka Bloody Mary,RIP

reviewText: Love these earlier pieces of Mulligans.  For the most part, very well done by this Trio.

I have owned this CD for at least 2 years, and I just listened to it again today, first time in about 2 months. It always sounds fresh and makes me laugh out loud with joy at about 4 minutes and 40 seconds of Black Nightgown when the boys bring  the tune home.You would not really have to be a Mulligan fan to get a charge out of this CD, just the playing is enough; for example listen to the bass solos on Festive Minor and Walkin' Shoes, and the bari sound at the beginning of Waltz For Geraldus.I wish the group would have a go at another CD. Are you listening Ronnie Cuber?

The quality is circa 68; but just hearing ernie harwell calling some of the games is worth it! Plus, I just love the sone ... "we're all behind our baseball team, go get 'em tigers, world series bound and picking up steam..."

I've been a lifelong Tigers fan (born in '59), so this CD of highlights from the 1968 season has been a real treat to listen to and add to my collection. Ernie Harwell and Ray Lane were a great broadcast team and to hear them talk about that magical season at Michigan & Turnbull, as well as the clips of play-by-play calls is a very enjoyable journey down Memory Lane!
As I have not heard the album I hope that this is an exact copy. Time will till as I have not yet had a chance to listen to it. I have heared part of it and am happy so far.

I purchased this CD when it was on vinyl back in 1971 . .And even though I grew up in Detroit, I was nevertheless a Baltimore Orioles fan as a kid at the time (believe me, I caught alot of %^&* for that at school).  Yet, to hear Ray Lane and Ernie Harwell once again on this CD brings back so many great memories for me and of those hot, humid summer nights back in Detroit with my Dad listing to all of this on the radio.  Remember, this is a compliation of snippets of radio broadcasts during the season, and at BEST you'll get a VERY general overview of particular games and points during the season (i.e., you are not going to hear an entire game, nor even an entire inning or even an at bat).  But to hear Harwell and Lane's commentary of Kaline or Freehan hitting one out, or Mickey Stanley making a great catch, this is a CD for those to reminisce; not to do a comprehensive in-depth study of the season itself.  And the background music when Lane and Harwell recount a season is very similar to the NFL films music used back during that time for team highlights as well . .So (in my estimation), it is doubly pleasurable.  The part of the CD that I love the best is when Dick McAlliff charges the mound in a game against the White Sox after Tommy John brushes him back and gets suspended for 5 games.  Ray Lane then goes on to describe how the Tigers begin to fall apart during their roadtrip to NY, and you really get a heightened sense of alarm as to how he calls this.  For me, this is radio broadcasting and commentary at its very best.  Professional, and not hokey like today where everybody tries to be a "Chris Berman knockoff."If you're a Tigers fan, you will love this (especially if you lived there during the 68 season).  If you're not a Tigers fan, I still say that you will enjoy this CD, as it will provide insight as to why we in Detroit think Ernie Harwell was the perfect sportscaster.

This CD is great! As a bari player, this is one of the best CDs I've ever listened to. The three bari Mulligan arrangements are really well done. It's great to hear so many awesome bari players play together. Get this CD!

My boyfriend is blind, and mentioned to me before Christmas that he would love to find some recordings of old Tiger games.  Of course I took my search to Amazon.  He absolutely loved The Year of the Tiger '68.  I am anxious to see if anything else similar is available for him.

I purchased this for my brother who was recuperating from foot surgery. He was thrilled with it and listened to it multiple times. He said he remembered many of the events when they originally happened and enjoyed reliving them again.
Had this on LP - originally from Michigan and was at game they won the American league pennant, putting them in the World Series.

One of the main things STP tried to do on Purple was to differentiate themselves from critics who called them "Seattle-Lite."  As a result, Purple is a very different album from Core.  Some songs like "Vasoline" still display a hard rock quality, but the rest of the CD is very different, and more melodic than their previous efforts.  A lot of it actually seems inspired by '70's rock.  In fact, this whole CD is terrifically wacky...from the odd picture of the birthday cake on the back to the squirrels that adorn the corners of the songbook pages, this is a really wacky, great CD, and does a lot to give STP their own unique, distinct sound.

Stone Temple Pilots second album, Purple is their best album ever. Stanout tracks include: Kitchenware and Candy Bars, Interstate Love Song, Big Empty, and Vasoline. All the songs are catchy, timeless, and creative. If you are a huge STP fan, this is the album that made them one of the best grunge bands of the '90s. Buy this gem today!

A suprisingly good album, with the singles Vasoline, Interstate Love Song, and the Power Ballad: Big Empty. With 12 Gracious Melodies (as the back of the CD says) including the odd, but good, bonus track. Meat Plow is good, STP rock. As is Vasoline. Lounge Fly is a liitle different, courtosey of some untradional drum and guitar playing. Interstate Love Song's jangly guitars may take a few listens to be appriciated. Likewise,  Still Remains is an aquired taste. Pretty Penny REALLY sounds like Polly from Nirvana's Nevermind, but with it's accoustic sound and catchy beat, it's very good. Silvergun Superman & "Unglued" are both hard rock and very good. Big Empty is also quite good, highlighting Dean DeLeo's slide quitair and Scott Weiland's Trying-not-to-sound-like-Eddie Vedder's voice. Army Ants has a physicadelic intro, but eventually turns into fast hard rock. Kitchenware & Candybars is another power ballad. My Second Album is a suprise I shall not spoil. Thanks to the afformentioned Stott and Dean, Robert DeLeo's bass and Eric Krets's drumming, with the DeLeo brothers writing most of the songs, this album is very cool.
in my opinion the best album front to back of all time. How someone was able to compile this masterpiece is beyond me. Seriously, don't even hesitate for 2 seconds before buying this cd.

Meatplow/Interstate love song/vasoline... what great rock anthems.  Grunge aside, these songs would go to number one right now with a bullet.  All grunge was in the first place was just reborn black sabbath, with catchy hooks and sing song kiss like choruses.  This cd is great for those very reasons.  If you love music that you can tap your feet to, and listen without any worries in your mind, this is a great CD to do it with.

This review is directly related to the qualities of the 2013 vinyl import release featured here. (I'm assuming you already know the band and the music). I have been collecting vinyl records for 20+ years, have an arguably decent, tube-based but not insanely expensive audiophile quality system and quite a trained ear to tell well made remasters from so-so ones. Vinyl re-releases these days are often a hit and miss deal. Just because an album is re-released on vinyl is not a guarantee that it will sound by default better than the CD version - a lot of technical factors come into play, different masters need to be made for the vinyl release, the physical limitations of the format, the quality of your own playback equipment and so on. However, I'm happy to report that MOV's vinyl re-release of this Stone Temple Pilots album is excellent in all counts, with an airy, ample soundstage and emphasis where it counts the most for a rock band - on the midrange. Presence of both instrumentation and vocalists is almost tridimensional, studio tape playback quality. I think I couldn't ask for more in terms of product quality, even if it comes somewhat pricey due to being an import release.
this album is pretty. track twelve is the best track since the reagan administration.

The 1968 Tigers played old fashioned baseball.  They played 162 games, and at the end of the season, if they were at the top of the standings, they won a pennant.  Period.  They were the best of the best in their league.  Their pitchers lasted nine innings. They won with a team batting average of .235, and, if their shortstop hit .135, he saved two or three runs for ever one he didn't knock in.  Occasionally '68 pitchers hit or scored winning runs themselves. It didn't matter how the team one, they were going to win one way or another.  All of the men on that team have places in history in a way far superior to anything mere membership in the Hall of Fame can give.  Collectively, the '68 Tigers would make mincemeat out of the teams of AAA players that make up most of today's "major league" rosters. In 1968, they won a World Championship and, in the process,  just saved a city, is all.  And this recording is of the way it all sounded when described by none other than the legendary Ernie Harwell.  What's not to like?  And, as it's a DVD, the record won't even warp if your forget and leave it on a sunny windowsill!
summary: Last real World Champions as chronicled by one of the better announcers ever

reviewText: In retrospect, 'Purple' is the most unique album to come out of the grunge period. It has style, hard rocking riffs, great melodies, sing-a-long lyrics,  and on top of that a very diverse/ecclectic collection of well recorded, wonderfully crafted songs.The significance of this album is that it shows a band who is no longer just going through the motions, but is actually creating and evolving into true 'songwriters and arraingers'. Each song has it's own character and feel which is almost absent from all other 'Grunge' releases of it's time. They are all unique and diverse, but they don't lose their edge and wit.The prominent melodic bass lines (Mr DeLeo is very underrated) and unique chord structures (So is the other Mr. DeLeo) are what brings life to these recordings.STP have always delivered with each album they've released. They are great songwriters, and I feel that this album is the perfect summation of all of their works. Rock, pop/rock, accoustic, funky/groovy, psychadelic... It's all here.One of the top 10 albums of the 90's!!All the best, -AndyMan-
summary: A Musicians review of this album...

When Stone Temple Pilots released Purple in the early '90s they, found themselves pigeonholed by the era: "grunge" (an unfortunate term) was the order of the day and STP were laid side by side with the likes of Pearl Jam, Alice in Chains and Nirvana in the music press.Purple, the Stone Temple Pilots' sophomore release, was a huge hit in its day, becoming the unquestionable soundtrack for an era, several of the tracks instantly recognizable to this day. Audiences loved and love them. Critics, however, have been slower to catch up.Nearly a decade on, it's clear that STP isn't and never was a "grunge" band at all; Stone Temple Pilots are a classic rock and roll outfit in the grand tradition, more Zeppelin than Vedder no matter how you slice it. And Purple, far from the pop-grunge fad it had been labeled, has aged better than most any other music of the era. With the spectre of the "grunge press" gone, music critics can now see what the fans saw all along: Purple is a modern classic, one of the greatest rock and roll albums since the rock and roll era began -- with playful, intelligent yet touching and reflective lyrics and a set of monster hooks and subtle riffs that make the album instantly listenable and eminently hum-alongable. There isn't an ounce of filler to be found on Purple.Since Purple, the Stone Temple Pilots have continued on to produce a string of quality albums on the forefront of music industry relevance that the critics have increasingly warmed to, without once dropping a dud on the market. Purple remains the disc that really launched them, an album that defined a generation and found STP, one of the quintessential rock acts of our time, finding their voices.
summary: Underestimated in it's time; one of the greatest ever.

reviewText: Purple is the album that takes you to a another place.  I thought "Bat out of Hell" by Meatloaf was a hard to beat on a those long drives through the countryside, but the Stone Temple Pilots have come close  with this one. Best heard with the volume 'Cranked Up' to the fullest.

reviewText: Nothing like their 1992 release with Core but equally as good, the distorted riffs are toned down on this album and Weiland sings in a totally different style, a true testiment to his abilities as a vocalist, often agreed by many to be their best album, Purple is an alt-rock classic and one of the most creative records of the 90's, songs like Vasoline and the always amazing Interstate Love Song, which everyone likes, fan of the group or not remain radio staples today, even the lesser known songs easily could have been singles. How the beautiful "Still Remains" never became a single will continue to baffle me
summary: STP completely revamp their entire sound

1994's "Purple" retains the heavy guitar sound of their debut, but adds a much more colorful palate of influences along with it.There's grinding, confrontational songs like "Meatplow", "Silvergun Superman", and the brooding "Lounge Fly". They're all heavy, but ripe with infectious radio hooks.Songs like "Vasoline" and "Unglued" are very fast and intense, but also incredibly catchy. Both also contain wicked guitar solos."Internstate Love Song" is a modern rock classic. It's breezy and pop friendly, but it still rocks at the same time. The main guitar riff is so catchy that it alone becomes the song's hook."Still Remains" is just..WOW. A glorious meeting of the ways between dream-pop, carefree psychadelia, and rock. Scott Weiland gives a passionate vocal performance on this one."Kitchenware & Candybars" is another un-Core sounding song with meditative, accoustic verses and a swirling chorus. The bridge in particular is very majestic with its orchestral flourishes.Other highlights include the introspective "Big Empty" (which perfects the soft/loud dynamics) and the raucous "Army Ants".If you don't already own this album, please..do so. It's STP's most consistent album, bridging the gap between the grunge sound of their debut album "Core", and the more experimental pop/psychedelic/etc influenced music of their later albums.Best Songs: Interstate Love Song, Still Remains, Big Empty, Kitchenware & Candybars, Lounge Fly.
summary: One of the best rock albums of the 90's

reviewText: Seriously this album is way awesome. Any fan of STP or rock music in general should pick this up. Interstate Love Song is an instant classic by any measure, along with this whole album.
Stone Temple Pilots are amazing. My two favorite songs on this albumn are Interstate Love Song and Big Empty. The CD was in great condition when I got it.

Since Purple's release, so much has been said about it that I would be lying if I said I were going to bring anything new to the table.  I do, however, have my perspective, and my experience with the album.Since I got into music heavily some six years ago, this has been the album I have listened to most.  Though I would call Pearl Jam my favorite band, STP has undoubtedly received the most stereo play in my house.  Why?The answer lies in the sheer excellence of this album.  It is no where near as heavy as most of Pearl Jam's work (conceptually, as in the lyrics, as opposed to instrumentation), but still manages to be relevant, heart wrenching and encouraging.  Try to hear "If you should die before me ask if you can bring a firend" and not feel some flicker of emotion run through you.  Ponder that line.  Would you want to be dead alone?The album is not without its faults, though.  For one, I rarely have gotten past the eighth or ninth track.  I do not know whether this is because I at one time deemed the second half unworthy, or because STP stacked the best parts of its line up at the beginning.  I do know that the end of the CD might be as foreign to me today as the day I bought it.Returning to the high points, I love the sound that STP puts across here.  They sound as if they are travelling in a direction that had not been explored much at that time.  They are climbing out of grunge and into somewhat of a nuclear fallout:  they combine grunge, classic seventies rock, and their own stylings to liven up their record.Buy this album!

reviewText: I had this in cassette when I was a teenager and I loved it so I decided I needed to own it again.  Love It

Let me put it this way:90s "Alt-Grunge Rock"  doesn't get much better than this.It's a sure winner if you like any of these bands:Alice-In-ChainsSmashing PumpkinsNirvanaPearl JamMudhoneyThen again if you like those bands you probably know who STP is, and have this album......oh well.

Stone Temple Pilots have always been, in my book, an essential band to rock. Lead by one of the best frontmen rock has seen in years you'd think that was all this band had going for it, but no. You also have a band that even outshine Scott at times, and that is saying a lot about how great this band is. In my mind I think if they were still together making music they'd be the rulers of their genre, God knows they were in the '90s alongside Pearl Jam. As for this CD, I can't find a single song I don't like. From beginning to end this is one of the best releases in over a decade. It's got the radio anthems (Vasoline, Interstate Love Song, Big Empty), and you've got the songs that didn't get airtime yet are still just as good as the singles (Meatplow, Lounge Fly, Unglued). If anyone doubted STP could top Core, they were proven wrong with this release.Starting with Meatplow was a wise decision, it bridges the gap between releases very well. Meatplow moves through the verses and choruses with ease, there's no slow point to this song. Vasoline is the reason I ended up getting this CD. At first it didn't sound like STP but after repeated listens it just gets into your head and you're stuck singing it to yourself days after hearing it. Lounge Fly is a pretty consistent song that stays stalled in between hard and light music. While the music is pretty hard throughout, Scott just sings throughout the song. I have no complaints though, I think his voice is perfect any way he uses it. Interstate Love Song has got to be one of my top ten favorite songs of all time. I've heard it an uncountable amount of times yet it still sounds fresh, like the day I heard it for the first time. I can't help of thinking of a summer day when I hear it. Pretty Penny is one of the best rock ballads I've heard in recent memory. Although it grows a bit stale over repeated listens the lyrics still beg your attention. I'm hardpressed to think of a song so touching. While Big Empty is a bit flat through the verses the chorus simply soars, Scott's voice has yet to be better. The lyrics aren't extremely good but the mood and way they are presented makes for a great song. Kitchenware & Candybars is, I feel, the best way to end this CD. It's not as hard hitting as Core was so there's no need to end with a song like Where The River Goes. No, just a brooding song dripping with emotion like Kitchenware does is more than you could ask for. It's only fitting that this CD ends this way too. The not so hidden track is a comedic listen at best, although I do wish they would've just faded out with Kitchenware. But no big complaints about it, it just reminds you that this is a band who enjoys making music.All in all my favorite songs are Meatplow, Vasoline, Interstate Love Song, Big Empty, and Kitchenware & Candybars. I feel that whether you like commercial rock or underground rock, whatever kind of music you listen to, you will be able to see the beauty this CD contains. Hands down, this is one of the best CDs of the 90s, not to mention STPs best. If you have yet to hear this then you should feel ashamed letting a gem like this go unheard.
summary: Fine place for a day full of breakdowns

The music is amazing.  We can get that out of the way because this review is for the Music On Vinyl reissue.  I also have the translucent purple original pressing, so I am fortunate enough to have a comparison.ARTWORK:The jacket artwork on the reissue is very blurry like the CD cover was blown up whereas the original pressing is very sharp and high resolution.  The insert in the reissue is identical to the original, except that it is now 2 pages folded and there is additional artwork of the original master tapes. Very cool!  MOV has confirmed that the record was actually cut from 192kHz/24bit digital archives of the master tapes, however, and you can actually see the stickers on the master tape boxes indicating that they were digitally archived.VINYL QUALITY:I have the purple Purple vinyl and the pressing itself is on-center and dead quiet.  I'd like to say that's normal for MOV, but it's been a bit hit or miss for this audiophile geared reissue company.  For comparison, my lightly used original pressing  is way off center on side B, and the vinyl is extremely noisy, so this is a breath of fresh air in that regard.SOUND QUALITY:The sound is quite distinctively and unusually different from the CD and original pressing.  "Unusually" because for most vinyl pressings, you have to really think about the sound improvements vs the digital equivalent, but that is certainly not the case for this copy.  While the original pressing is obviously cut from the CD master leaving any sound differences up to your equipment, this reissue is an entirely different beast.  Where the original mastering sounds V shaped (boosted bass, lowered mid, boosted treble), this sounds completely opposite (A shaped?), and is also a bit more centered which is becoming the norm for MOV (I like a wide soundstage, but I guess they don't).  It's hard to explain, but it sounds awesome until you compare it to the CD.  Basically if you drop the needle and sit back and listen, it sounds wonderful.  But, if you then decide to cue up the CD to the same spot and flip over to it, it's a total shock how different it sounds, and it's kind of like "Oh yeah, that's how I remember it sounding, but now it doesn't sound very good, it's too thin and harsh".  So then you switch it back to the vinyl and now all the sudden it sounds really weird because there's a ton of mid and no bass or sparkle in the treble, so now that doesn't sound good anymore either.  Basically- pop on the vinyl and enjoy it, and don't give in to the urge to compare or else you'll be disappointed all around.
summary: 2013 Vinyl is good but very different

reviewText: I have heard most of the songs from "Core",so I decided to check out "Purple". I had already heard of Big Empty and Interstate Love Song many times. I bought this CD with expectations of the same stuff as "Core".To my suprise this CD has its own originality. It is full of good hard rock songs with Meatplow, Vasoline, and Unglued. There are also many quiter songs, Interstate Love Song, Big Empty.Their isn't one song that I dislike on this CDMeatplow- 9.5/10 Good openerVasoline- 10/10 First Single, very catchyLounge Fly- 9/10Interstate Love Song- 10/10 Quiet Song, very goodStill Remains- 9/10Pretty Penny- 8/10 A little strange, but very goodSilvergun Superman- 9/10 Hard, very goodBig Empty- 10/10 another quiet song, one of the best on the CDUnglued- 10/10 Probably my favorite on CD, harder rockArmy Ants- 9/10Kitchenware & Candybars- 9/10 kinda depressing but overall good songBonus Track- 6/10 really wierd and not so great, but i guess why its a bonus track.

STPs most consistent effort. While later albums like "Tiny Music" and "No. 4" yielded some of STP's best (as well as most stylistically daring) songs, "Purple" will probably remain their best start-to-finish hard rock effort.And that's one of two things they do better than anyone else. It's strange that other band's can't generate simple but powerful tunes like "Unglued" or "Vasoline," songs that groove and explode using no more than a few chords and a few lines of lyrics. STP seems to hold the current patent on tuneful, quality hard rock. Or is it pop rock? Or alternative?The other, and more surprising, thing they do better than anyone else these days is craft a good song. Every album has at least one melody that McCartney would like (even if it's enmeshed in full-throttle power chording). "Unglued" and "Vasoline" have the hooks to sing (actually scream) along to, and "Pretty Penny," "Interstate Love Song," and "Big Empty" each put forth good sing-alongs in interesting atmospherics.And then you get the bonus of groovy/trippy rockfests like "Army Ants," which sounds like the kind of song Smashing Pumpkins wish they could write (you also get Weiland's voice, which Billy Corgan, if he's wise, would himself wish for).
summary: STPs Second Best, but Most Consistent

reviewText: As many albums come and go, some leaves us wanting more, gasping for air, and asking how this masterpiece was made... this is one of those albums.The second hard hitting compolation of stone temple pilots, PURPLE is a crowning achivement for the group, for they came out with a critisized second album (like any new band), and delivered.  The first song MEATPLOW Gives a strong sound with a preaching, paranoid sound to it that is sotthed by the words "I got a lover and she shows me how to understand..."The whole album is full with loud and strong classic songs, raw ballads that defy the stereotype of soft, emotional ballads, and lyrics only a master of articulate expressions can produce.the last song "kitchenware and candybars" is, in my opinion the highlight of the album, but if you would like to hear it yourself I suggest you buy this album... a must have!  :)

What a strong release from one of the most underrated bands of the 90's. Honestly if you love 90's rock, this is more than a must, but a necessity. Besides the fact that the music rocks your socks off, you have got to love the lyrics. I mean just fantastic lyrics, that fit perfectly like a finished puzzle. What's cool about this too is i don't think it says anywhere on the album that this album is even called purple. I guess maybe that chinese symbol means purple, i don't know, either way that's kind of cool. ANyways it's got great riffs, and awesome melodies to keep you rockin forever.

It's no secret to anyone that knows me that Stone Temple Pilots is one of my favorite bands of all time, but I am also very honest about the albums they put out and after 'Purple' things started to go downhill thanks to the continued drugs problems of Scott Weiland.  After the amazing debut album 'CORE' (one of, if not my favorite album of all time), STP was able to record Purple in only a matter of weeks.  It's quite clear that STP were at their creative best at this time in their careers and it shows in their music here.Quick Track By Track Review:01. Meatplow - Great riff, good lyrics, solid song ****02. Vasoline - One of the best of the ablum *****03. Lounge Fly - Some of the best music on the entire album, great effort here ****04. Interstate Love Song - One of STP's most beloved songs ever ****05. Still Remains - Horribly undervalued song, truely beautiful and deserves more recognition *****06. Pretty Penny - Fair song, my 2nd least favorite on the album ***07. Silvergun Superman - Weiland's words just are riveting, great effort ****08. Below Empty - One of STP's top 10 songs of all time *****09. Unglued - Tons of energy in this song, awesome work here ****10. Army Ants - Worst song on the album and the only track that I don't like, a sign of the STP to come **11. Kitchenware & Candybars - Beautiful track made better when you MP3 it and cut out the hidden track down to 4 minutes of pure musical bliss ****Folks, you can't go wrong with this album.  If you want to hear what music was like in the early 90s and see how good STP was at the time, do yourself a favor and pick this wonder up.***** HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
I must say this easily stands next to Pearl Jam Ten as one of the most defining albums of the 90s.
summary: When I think of the 90s, I see Purple

reviewText: Core may have hit harder,& Tiny Music may mix bravery with bubblegum,but Purple is where STP shed the quipes at being the "Stone Gossard  Pilots".They come into they're own sound as well as bring in  a varied mix of songs.Interstate Love Songs is the best of the lot as well  as the hypnotic Vasoline.Big Empty is superior to the similarly sounding  Creep(from Core).Even the non singles stand up well(Meatplow,Pretty  Penny,and the third track which slips my mind at the moment).Even if the  industry washes STP of their hands(due to Scott Wieland's recent woes and  no.4's less-than-stellar chart performance)Purple will stand as the one  album where they survived the barbs as well as the sophmore slump.

Core may have hit harder,& Tiny Music may mix bravery with bubblegum,but Purple is where STP shed the quipes at being the "Stone Gossard Pilots".They come into they're own sound as well as bring in a varied mix of songs.Interstate Love Songs is the best of the lot as well as the hypnotic Vasoline.Big Empty is superior to the similarly sounding Creep(from Core).Even the non singles stand up well(Meatplow,Pretty Penny,and Lounge Fly).Even if the industry washes STP of their hands(due to Scott Wieland's recent woes,Shangra-La-Dee Da's less-than-stellar chart performance,and the unpredictable status of the band)Purple will stand as the one album where they survived the barbs as well as the sophmore slump.

this is a great follow up to core.  stand outs are meatplow, big empty, vasoline and my favorite; interstate love song.  all of these are still in heavy rotation on the radio.  after song #11 ends DONT TURN OFF THE RADIO JUST YET!  keep it playing and another song starts playing, gracious melodies.  its more comical than serious.  the guy has a real cheesy sounding voice.  actually sounds like he is some sort of vegas lounge singer.  if you like this band get this, core and thank you (a greatest hits compilation) and thats about all you should need.  also check out velvet revolver if you like scott weiland him and slash put something together after STP broke up.

Purple was the first time I had heard of Stone Temple Pilots, and then I listened to the rest, becoming an instant fan. What this album does is abandon the Core sound and really gets into that grunge mode, but they do it gracefully, and looking back, everyone knows they succeeded. This did not intend to compare with what Nirvana was doing, producing some good catchy tunes like Meatplow, Vasoline, Big Empty, and of course, Interstate Love Song. It belongs in every music fan's CD collection. Nuff said.

Accused of mimicking Pearl Jam, Stone Temple Pilots took two years after its debut (1992's core) to produce this astounding, strange, and utterly fascinating album containing some of the band's best compositions, a newer,  better sense of lyrics, and better performances all around.Purple is  almost pop-music in its songwriting approach, with emphasis on big,  throbbing hooks, sharp production, and execution.  "Meat Plow"  opens the album on a sneer and a bristling beat, and then  "Vasoline" announces the band's intent to experiment.  Two notes  on a guitar tell the story, and Scott Weiland's unusually nuanced singing  combine for the strangest grunge anthem since Alice in Chains'  "Would?".  "Pretty Penny" finds the band in dreamy  territory with its best ballad ever, hands down, Weiland's singing  evocative and emotive; "Big Empty" has dynamics and huge surges  of guitar; "Still Remains" is infectious in its melody, imagery  and sexual tension; and "Interstate Love Song" is another  anthemic crunch a la "Plush", the biggest modern-rock hit of its  time (a record it held until a year or two ago).  The album suckerpunches  yet again at the end with the incredibly weird but maddeningly catchy  lounge tune (not performed by the band) that thumbs its nose at  conventional album recording and is another showcase of the sense of humour  that Stone Temple Pilots have begun to mine.Very worthy, very catchy  rock and roll; an album that begins to carve STP an identity independent of  its forerunners.

The massive success of Stone Temple Pilots debut album "Core" (1992) was something of a mixed blessing for the group. While the album was a runaway smash, ultimately selling eight million copies and spawning such radio staples as "Plush," "Sex Type Thing" and "Creep," success definitely came at a price. Almost immediately the San Diego group was viciously and mercilessly attacked and ripped apart by the press. Accusations of ripping off the Seattle grunge scene and jumping on the flavor of the month alternative bandwagon were the most common complaints. "Plush," in particular was singled out as plagiarizing Pearl Jam.Truth be told, these accusations were not without merit. While the band insisted that the bulk of "Core" was written as far back as 1988, the album did sound derivative of the Seattle soundbook. Released in 1992, "Core" blended the punkish riffs of Nirvana, the baritone growls and stylistic craft of Pearl Jam, and the metallic crunch of Alice In Chains. But with "Core," the album was ultra radio friendly, the songs ultra infectious, which made the album both a smash hit and a number one target.Was "Core" a rip-off? Maybe. A great record? Most defiantly. But where to go from there?Stone Temple Pilots had a lot to prove with their sophomore album. The second album is often the hardest, as the "sophomore slump" is not uncommon. With their credibility and integrity under so much criticism, STP had to not only come up with a great bunch of songs, they also had to stretch their artistic muscle, lest their critics label them a disingenuous, opportunistic one-album-wonder.Recoded in just one month, STP's sophomore album "Purple" was released in the spring of 1994. Compared to "Core," "Purple" is a far leaner, muscular album, sounding far less generic. While "Purple" doesn't sound 180 degrees radically different from the debut, much of the borrowing of the sounds of the Seattle "big four" (Nirvana, Pearl Jam, Soundgarden, Alice In Chains) is left behind as STP was starting to find their own voice. With their second album the band sounds tighter, more cohesive. Dean DeLeo's riffs and solos should have been a breath of fresh air for anyone longing for the days of 70s guitar-heavy AOR. Vocalist Scott Weiland, always one for experimenting with sounds (just look at his underrated 1998 solo album "12 Bar Blues") gives the songs a lot of color, making them far above average. Eric Kretz (drums) and Robert DeLeo (bass) as always, provide an exciting and dynamic rhythm section.Many fans/critics/reviewers have labeled "Purple" a "grunge" album. Truth be told, however, "Purple" doesn't really have the characteristics of the grunge sound. Grunge is all about "the fuzz" with intense drumming, feedback, a "dirty" guitar, etc. Bands like Nirvana, Mudhoney, early Soundgarden, Hole, Green River, etc, exemplified the grunge sound. "Purple," by comparison, is far more commercial. STP was never meant to be an underground band with street cred, as the band lusted after the arenas from day one.  STP wrote songs that were made to be played on the radio, not Sub Pop compilations. And while "Core" borrowed from the Seattle scene, "Purple" sees a strong Zeppelin/Sabbath influence, with psychedelic trimmings. In addition, there was nothing anarchic about STP; their songs were well-crafted and, at the risk of sounding cynical, calculated.  So to call "Purple," a grunge album is incorrect. Rather, "Purple" is a fine collection of 70s inspired, muscular hard-rock with a twist of psychedelia.The grinding, sludgy "Meat Plow" gets things off to a great start and would make Tony Iommi himself proud. The classic "Vasoline," a modern-rock staple, is one of the band's all-time greats. The Zeppelin-like riff and strong melody make it incredibly infectious and rock hard. The album takes an unexpected psychedelic twist with "Lounge Fly," throwing the listener a curve-ball. The track actually sounds a bit like Hendrix's "Are you Experienced?" Destined to be played on classic rock stations in 20 years time, "Interstate Love Song," which was the number-one mainstream rock song for nearly four months, is another vintage STP classic. The majestic "Still Remains" is big and epic in scope, swooping up the listener in a colorful sea of sounds. The sparse "Pretty Penny" sounds akin to "Friends" from "Led Zeppelin III" (1970). The hard-rocking "Silvergun Superman" wouldn't have sounded out-of-place on "Core" and while not the album's strongest cut, keeps up the momentum. Featured on the "Crow" (1994) soundtrack, the epic, ominous "Big Empty" was another smash from "Purple" and remains a 90s classic. While most of "Purple" avoided sounding derivative of anything Seattle, the bone-crunching "Unglued" and "Army Ants" sound very Nirvana-esque. However, these two cuts are so infectious, with such great hooks and rock so hard; STP is given a free pass. The haunting, ambitious "Kitchenware and Candybars" concludes the album nicely. Just when you think the album is done, however, you are hit with the totally bizarre "the second album" an unlisted bonus track (thus making "Purple" a collection of "12 gracious melodies.") Much like how the closing "My World" from Guns N' Roses "Use Your Illusion II" (1991) stuck out like a sore thumb, this lounge-lizard ditty is totally out-of-place, but it's cool in its own way and works.With a little bit of Sabbath, Zeppelin, psychedelia, Nirvana and a lounge number thrown in the mix, "Purple" is a pretty cool, diverse collection of songs. In some ways, "Purple" is somewhat of an underrated album. While "Purple" is generally regarded as the band's best work, many of its songs are over-looked. While "Purple" is renowned for its big singles ("Vasoline," "Interstate Love Song," "Big Empty") the album is chock-full of memorable great songs.With "Purple" STP proved that they were no one-album-wonder. They fought back accusations of trend-hopping by writing a memorable, eclectic collection of songs, much to the chagrin of their detractors. So while many figured STP to be just a flash-in-the-pan, with "Purple," STP proved that they were just getting started...

I was a freshman in high school when this album hit. It's just as awesome now as it was then. CORE was a fantastic debut, but the band completely obliterates the "sophomore sump" and prove they're a band to be remembered. Looking back on their discography in 2010, I have to say PURPLE is still the crown jewel of their catalogue. Buy this now.

reviewText: Despite the criticism this group faced by being told that they were ripping off the major bands from Seattle, they continued to stand strong with this follow-up.  Some of the best-known songs on here are the rockin' "Vasoline", the light rock of "Interstate Love Song" & the pseudo-ballad "Big Empty" which was also a part of the soundtrack for the movie, The Crow.  One other noteworthy song is the acoustic "Pretty Penny."  These songs are good, the CD is pretty decent over all.

STP grew. What else can you say?The first album was somewhat limited to grunge...this album is different. It still has grunge efforts, but they  have a more extensive range in this one.Buy this CD if only for the  hits: "Interstate Love Song" held it's own with the group's other  SUPER hit "Plush" from "Core." ILS stayed number one on  the charts for 17 weeks and is one of the most known songs of the 90s. The  same can be said about "Plush" and it could take hours to figure  out which one really was the bigger hit...however any group that could  produce two songs that were so damn popular deserve to be in the hall of  fame.Two other smash hits on this one: "Vasoline," a simple  but excellent grunge anthem that secured STP's success, and "Big  Empty," the song everyone would know from "The Crow"  soundtrack. "Big Empty" is the better of the two...and I would  bet my LIFE that anyone would recognize it in the first five seconds of the  song. The cool slide guitar work and mysterious lyrics secured The Crow's  platinum status. Topping that off with one of the catchiest choruses of all  time, "Big Empty" is reason enough to by any album.Thankfully,  this album trimmed the filler from "Core." In the grunge  category, there is "Meatplow," a wonderful rocker with cool but  meaningless lyrics, and "Lounge Fly" which kinda sounds like  Alice In Chains in its own weird way.Alternative rockers are the  majority here:"Still Remains" is a preview of the mysticism  that would be all over their next (better) release, "Tiny  Music..." while the same can be said about "Pretty Penny"  and their latest release, No. 4."Silvergun Superman" is one of  STP's finest tunes, and is basic rock and roll that could have been  released in the 70s. It's chorus is classic STP...incredibly catchy, even  to the harshest critic."Unglued" is a groovy alt-rocker that  was actually a minor hit with FM radio. Scott's lyrics really fit the mood  of the music ("Moderation is masturbation, what is what and what makes  you feel good?") and it will leave you wanting more.Such comes with  "Army Ants," with it's mysterious opening and catchy riffs it is  also one of the best STP songs ever recorded. The solo is  amazing.Surprisingly the only one I'm not crazy about is the final song,  "Kitchenware and Candybars." The lyrics are good, the guitar is  so-so, but it seems to repetetive to match up with the rest of the  album.Although the critical acceptance didn't come until their next  album (which is far more ambitious and original than this one), this was  the height of their popularity, selling nine million copies and containing  some of the biggest hits of the 90s.
summary: Better than "Core"...not as good as the next two...

reviewText: This album will be reviewed song by song as usual. 10 point scale. 10 = Absolutely amazing, 1 = Banging on a Tin CanMeatplow, 8, Great opener with great guitar riffs and the usual great singing by Scott. Just a classic good song by these guys.Vaseline, 10, Defenetly one of my favorite STP songs that most everybody has heard. Has incredibly great and catchy lyrics that you have to sing to. It also has a really cool unique sound to it that I love.Lounge Fly, 9, A great great power ballad. They used to play the beginning of this song for the intro to TRL but I don't know if they do anymore. Great guitar work.Interstate Love Song, 8, This song is good and catchy and made for the radio. It was as big of a hit as Plush but in my mind doesn't come even come close to comparing in quality.Still Remains, 7, This song is saved by Scott. The guitar riffs in this are rather annoying and don't seem to really go anywhere but Scott's great vocals make this song pretty good.Pretty Penny, 8, Ooo this song is sooooo good. I can't really describe it you have to listen to it, it really is good. Just a perfectly balanced song.Silvergun Superman, 8, Dang another really good song. Great guitar riffs and really good vocals by Scott again. I wish I could describe how good it is.Big Empty, 10, Simply put an absolutely amazing song. I haven't met anyone who doesn't like this song. Soooo catchy. Tiiiiimmmmmmeeeeee to take her home.Unglued, 7,  This song always makes me laugh because of the lyrics. Moderation is masturbation, I think thats what he says. Anyways even though it makes me laugh it's a great song with a great guitar solo in it.Army Ants, 8, A great song with a cool beginning and a great solo in the middle somewhere if I remember correctly. Anywhoo once again a great song.Kitchenware and Candybars, 9,  I'm not really sure where the title comes from this is simply a great song. I love how in the middle it changes from acoustic to electric guitar. OOOO I love it, wonderful song.A score of 8 or better means that a song is great. This album has 9 songs that fit this category and no songs that fall below a score of 7. Simply put there are no bad songs on this album period. This is defenetly one of the Top 10 best albums of all time, along with CORE, also by the Stone Temple Pilots.

STP continued their high songwritting/playing standards in this 1994 album, their second effort following their big hit album CORE.Actually all their albums preceding the departure of vocalist/lyricist Scott Weiland (to be a member of Velvet Revolver for a couple of albums)are consistently very good R'n'R albums with the occasional ballad.You won't be disappointed.

We don't hear anything from the STP anymore.  It's our loss.  Overshadowed by the bitterly cerebral Kurt Cobain and Pearl Jam Eddie Vedder's bombastic, sonorous voice--and being emotionally more akin to Radiohead--the STP spent several albums trying to claw their way out of the flannelled scene of the times, all the while being accused--often correctly--of mimicking other bands.With Purple, they got it right.  The DeLeo brothers' incredible songwriting paired with Weiland's lyrics to form an accreted image of a self-punishing naif flailing--but not quite drowning--in the wicked world.  Life's aches and pains permeated all these tunes, the best of which--Interstate Love Song, Big Empty, Lounge Fly, Vaseline, the ridiculously named and shockingly good "Meatplow" --plead for understanding in the face of complete relational impasse.Too, Weiland's voice was an unsung hero, as it were: a flexible, reedy tenor bouncing between raw and warm vibratto--far prettier than he was ever given credit for.  The DeLeos filled their songwriting with quirky, Byzantine chord progressions and hooks pounded out of guitars in a violent sludge that never, ever overwhelmed the searching tunes. And Eric Krentz' drumming drove these songs over a cliff into free-fall.  These men have done other work since (most notably 4's "Sour Girl, the best thing of their career) but Purple was the STP perfect storm--not one word or note rang false, and most of it was ravishing.  Years later, it still is.
summary: If you should die before me/ Ask if you could bring a friend

After a huge classic from the early 90's like CORE, the STONE TEMPLE PILOTS was at their peak of creativity and recorded this great album PURPLE!!!!! It's a great album, in par with CORE...GREAT PURPLE!!!! TOTALLY RECOMMENDED!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I'm willing to bet this is STP's overall best album. Here they expand their sound ("Pretty Penny" is mostly acoustic; "Lounge Fly" is, in order, 1/3 Guns n' Roses, 1/3 Crosby, Stills & Nash, and another third Guns n' Roses; "Interstate Love Song" is southern rock) sharpen their songwriting, and come up with something pretty damn good. Okay, so not "Silvergun Superman" or "Meat Plow", flat reworkings of the Core sound. Neither have much personality. I don't really like the slash-and-burn punk song "Unglued" either. It just sounds out of place. But man, "Interstate Love Song" makes up for all of that. The riffs, the vocals, the chorus and the opening are all absolutely perfect. Actually, the entire song is absolutely perfect. I don't think Soundgarden ever made a song as good as that. Or The White Stripes, while I'm at it. "Big Empty" does, too. It goes from slide-driven delta blues to hard-rock in the verses and choruses. You not only get a dynamic shift (which everyone was doing back then), but a stylistic shift, too! And "Army Ants" is a psychedelic hard southern rocker. They even go for a winding, four-minute epic (with hidden track attached, of course) on "Candybars and Kitchenware". A lot of bands would screw this up, but STP gets it perfectly! It's not as good as "Where the River Goes" from the last album, but I don't care, because it's a good song. The lounge-jazz hidden track, an ironic crooned "thank-you-for-listening", is pretty funny, too. I'd hesitate to call anything by the Pilots brilliant, but I enjoy this.
summary: One of the decade's best. No, I'm actually serious. Stop laughing

reviewText: What a follow-up! This one shows them playing and writing with more maturity and has a good balance between heavy and soft throughout. "Vasoline" was a tremendous hit for them. It is very edgy and  reminds me somewhat of skate-punk. Don't ask me why. "Interstate Love  Song" shows some of the aforementioned maturity and is my all-time  favorite STP song. Everything about it is great. That's about as much as I  can elaborate. Just listen to it yourself so you can get your own  impression. "Army Ants" is another edgy song and the opening  reminds me of something that Joe Satriani would do. Again, don't ask me  why. Last but not least, there is a hilarious bonus track which is on a few  minutes after the last song. It reminds me of Monty Python. I think they  mixed up the titles on this album. The BONUS track should have been called  "Lounge Fly." Anyway, if you're into alterative and don't have  this one yet, get it. It's a classic.
summary: Better than their first in some ways.

reviewText: This is the second album for the trippy 90's hard rock group. While STP was unfairly lumped in with the grunge-rockers of the era, STP was in reality a hard rock band, sounding straight out of say, 1975. All that with some grunge influnces, of course. This album includes some of the band's biggest hits, like 'Interstate Love Song', 'Big Empty', and 'Vasoline'. While not being as hard-drivingly heavy as the previous album, the band have not gone light. I love all of the songs on here. Scott's voice, I feel has matured a little bit, espescially on tracks like 'Big Empty', which gives a new meaning to the term 'power ballad'. Buy this album, it's a tried and true classic.

After hearing the great "Core", I wasn't expecting the follow-up to be much better but boy was I in for a surprise!  "Purple" is quirky and unexpected where "Core" was more predictable hard core grunge but "Purple" is also the much, much better album both in the quality of the songwriting and the complexity of the ideas of the tracks.No doubting that "Core" has a few killer tracks and "Plush" with its simple and yet complex sounding chords made me and my band want to cover as many of their tracks as we could but we found that we ended up covering more tracks on "Purple" instead because they were more interesting and fun to play.  That's the beauty of STP in that the De Leo brothers were never shy of experimenting with chords and they would purposely avoid playing a standard chord and look for more exotic ones to substitute them with.  "Plush" is a great example of this and it's so simple to play that even though all these years I haven't played it on the guitar, I still feel confident I can simply pick up my guitar and still play 90% of the piece without error."Purple" is almost like a jazz album in the way it's written and is a real enigma to me even to this day.  Starting out with the brilliant "MeatPlow" that is overflowing with exotic-sounding chords, the album moves on to one of my old band's favourite songs to warm up to, "Vasoline", and carries on to what can only be described as what country music would sound grunge style in "Interstate Love Song" one of my band's favourite tracks to cover.  The riffs and the intro has a distinctly country feel about them.Then we get the acoustic and excellent "Pretty Penny" which is a joy to play if you are into folk guitar because yet again, we get to play exotic chords all the way.  "Big Empty" is simply another beautiful track and is one of their best ever.  "Unglued" is the ultimate jam song and one of the easiest to play but sounds very complex indeed.All the tracks flow very nicely here and like any classic album, move the tracks in any other order and the overall album suffers for it.  I can't wait for a proper remastering job on this album and on "Core" with perhaps a mini-lp sleeve packaging design thrown in as well.By far, STP's best album and one of the best grunge albums of all time.  This is that rare album that both casual fans and musicians can truly appreciate as a genuine work of art.Very highly recommended!
summary: STP's Best Album By a Country Mile!  Needs Remastering Though!

reviewText: Stone Temple Pilots remind me of bands like Primus and The Cranberries, in the way that each bands debut was excellent, then each following album was weaker and weaker. Therefore I find "Purple" to be their second best album. Though not quite as hardcore as "Core", it's still rooted in grunge more than the following albums were, and the songs are still mostly strong front to back. "Meatplow" is a good opener, which leads to "Vasoline", one of their catchiest tracks ever. "Interstate Love Song" is another classic, and afterwards is "Still Remains", which I have always loved. Then there's the simple "Pretty Penny", and "Big Empty", also found on "The Crow" soundtrack. Everything else is still great, right down to the hidden track, which really does sound like Johnny Mathis.

Stone Temple Pilots got absolutely ripped apart by the press and rock fans after the release of their debut album Core for being facsimiles fo their grunge peers; I will admit that some of it was warranted, but it was as good a debut in rick as their has been in recent years. Obviously the criticism must have hurt; enter their second kick in the teeth, Purple. This was a turning point in STP's career, considering this album was relased two months after the death of grunge's poster boy, Kurt Cobain, and the musicial "trend" would soon follow him to the grave. Scott Weiland and Co. were obviously on a mission, taking what they had learned and listening to what was around them;listen to "Vasoline" and you'll hear a hint of Red Hot Chili Peppers funk, carried by the bass of Robert DeLeo. Then there's " Interstate Love Song", which in my opinion is just out of the top ten of the best hard rock songs of the 90's. They have taken the metallic element of their music,and replaced with catchy folk rock with pop appeal; if you haer any alternative bands that try to get hardcore(Incubus, Switchfoot,Lost Prophets,Chevelle, etc,), they can thank STP(and the Smashing Pumpkins, for that matter).
I love the video for "Vasoline", its so weird and cool! The song is just as cool. Interstate Love Song is another stand-out.David Rehakauthor of "A Young Girl's Crimes"

Stone Temple Pilots' "Purple" is a great album. After hearing songs like "Interstate Love Song" and "big Empty" on the radio, I had to buy the album. I was happy to hear that not only those songs, but almost every other song on the album is good. If you like the sound of pop/grunge, you should purchase this album as soon as possible.

I don't remember exactly what was expected of this album when it first came out in 1994.  However, I remember MTV all over Vaseline and Interstate Love Song.... something they would never do to a typical 2nd release CD.  STP strongly proves that they are a band of great credibilty, talent, and originality.  A must have for your collection!

I loved core when it came out. When they released purple i was excited and could not wait. I did not expect it to be better then core but was I wrong. This in my oppinion is still there best album. It has rockers like meatplow and vasolin it has slower songs like interstate love song and pretty penny. I know they were part of the grunge sceen in the 90's but they were much more than that. Here in 2006 this album is still an outstanding listen. Do your self a favor and purchase this album if you dont already own it.

I can't believe that some people would put Nirvana, Pearl Jam, and Alice and Chains above the Stone Temple Pilots.  You can't even compare them to this great album!  Interstate Love Song is one of the best songs written of all time.  The whole album is packed with heavy riffs, strong vocals, amongst many other things that make an album legendary.  STP have exceeded their full potential that they reached during Core.  It's nice to see a strong talented band in this generation.

I've said it before and I'll say it again...Stone Temple Pilots are TREMENDOUSLY underated.  STP sluffed their reputation as alternative wanna-bes with "Purple".  I'm on my 2nd copy of "Purple", having worn out my first copy years ago."Meatplow" blows the roof off the joint right from the get-go, leading to the capitol first single, "Vasoline".  I'd mention highlights, but EVERY song here is a poppy, hook-laden masterpiece.  Nothing like "Core", this great record really brought STP into their own.  It's still one of my favorite albums of the nineties.

Stone Temple Pilots (or Purple) (1994.), the Stone Temple Pilots' second studio albumThe early 90's were an explosive time for music. Alternative grunge rock had taken hold right at the start of the decade with bands like Pearl Jam, Soundgarden, Nirvana and Alice In Chains gaining widespread popularity. Plenty of other groups though were trying out the whole grunge trend. One of these bands was the Stone Temple Pilots. Originally coming on the scene in 1992 with their debut album 'Core', the 'Pilots were at first given the tag of being Pearl Jam rip-offs. However, with their debut the band showed they had the makings of becoming one of the great acts of the 90's. 'Stone Temple Pilots' (also known as 'Purple'), the Stone Temple Pilots second studio album, released in 1994 was the bands much awaited follow up to their successful first album. 'Purple' has in time grown to be the band's most popular album release. So, does 'Purple' really deserve the critical acclaim that it has been given.Let's make it simple; this album is a masterpiece. With this album, the Stone Temple Pilots totally found their sound. If their debut left some people writing the band off as rip-offs, 'Purple' completely smothers the idea. More than just a straight ahead hard rock, riff filled album, the Stone Temple Pilots reveal the more diverse side of their music, which is what in many ways gives the band their own identity and sets them apart from the pack. This album is alternative rock at its most refined. Breaking away from the 'grunge' mold (however you interpret that), this album is a mix of songs with powerful riffing (i.e. 'Meat Plow' or 'Silvergun Superman') and slower stuff (i.e. 'Big Empty'), plus not to forget the more diverse songs like the acoustically driven 'Pretty Penny'. On the whole, you can easily say that some of the band's best songs are on this album and you can tell this as the instrumentation and lyrics feel completely assured right through the album. Lead guitarist Dean DeLeo his brother bassist Robert DeLeo show how diverse guitar playing can be on this album, where we go from the harder more metal sounding riffs, to acoustic and country sounding moments. Scott Weiland's lyrics are at times crazy and other times powerful and cynical. However, the powerful vocal style the man has makes the words blend easily with the music. 'Purple' is quite simply one of those albums were all of the songs work without sounding out of place or inconsistent. 'Purple' is 11 years old but has that remarkably fresh appeal to it every time you listen to it.There is one thing though that really hacks me off about this album and the same goes for the album's follow up, 'Tiny Music'. You guessed it, its the back cover of the CD; there is no tracklisting. This is a mistake that you hope will be corrected in time because it always helps to be able to see whats on the album, especially when your viewing the CD over before buying it from a shop!So what about the 12 gracious melodies this album gives us. STP kick off their second album with 'Meat Plow', a heavy riffed opener. Weiland sings this one with a down and out style, a great opening song. 'Vasoline' fades in next, with some quirky guitar hooks and pronounced drumming. The chorus on this one is awesome where Weiland sings 'it isn't you, isn't me' to a great guitar riff. Next is 'Lounge Fly', a sonic sounding opening, with some more pounding riffs. Weiland's lyrics gives this song a pent up aggressive side. Things slow down next for 'Interstate Love Song', the guitar play is a perfect mix of hard riffs with a bit of a country sound. A great ballad styled song where Weiland sings about events past, and things/people you've left behind. 'Still Remains' keeps up the power driven riffs; again the band jam out a great chorus with some clever echoeing singing from Weiland. Eric Kretz drums out a great surprise entry towards the end of the track.'Pretty Penny' is one of the more diverse tracks on the album. Its got a great acoustic sound. Crazier lyrics follow with 'Silver Gun Superman'. You've gotta love the metal riffs to this one. For me though, 'Big Empty' is the greatest track on the album, Weiland yearns out the opening verse before the song builds into a great driving chorus, at its most powerful where Weiland screams 'conversations kill'. This song is a perfect mix of the bands melodic and experimental sides. The supercharged 'Unglued' follows, a 2 minute bashed out rocker that you NEVER get tired of playing again and again. 'Army Ants' starts suspiciously before building into another explosive song. However 'Kitchenware and Candybars' is a great change to finish the album. Again like a ballad, the song has a great orchestral addition at the end to accompany some luscious riffs and some emotive vocals. Keep this track running though for the twelfth song (its fixed onto track eleven), a funny song where Weiland sings about the 'second' album to the tune of trumpets and hammond organ!When people look back on the 90's era of music, yes they will think about the bands who set the trends like the Pearl Jam and others. However, im confident that the Stone Temple Pilots will also be remebered as one of the great alternative rock acts also, in no part due to this masterpiece of an album. This was the first STP album that I bought and I loved every minute of it from the first listen. A must for any rock fan; buy this CD, crank up the stereo and settle back and listen to 12 gracious melodies.
summary: One of the top moments of alternative 90's rock

reviewText: I'm torn as to which is the better STP CD, "Core" or "Purple."  My solution:  Buy them both!  This album is a great follow up to their debut CD, and features some of the band's best known songs, such as "Vasoline", "Big Empty", and my personal favorite, "Interstate Love Song".  Some consider STP to be a Pearl Jam knock-off (like more Pearl Jam is a bad thing??), but I'll be the first person to tell you that STP rock out in their own right. Buy this album!
summary: One time a thing occured to me...

reviewText: Purple is quite possibly one of my favorite albums of all time. Ironically, No.4 is my fav. STP album. I simply love both.What makes this album stand-out the most is the hit single "Interstate Love Song." This song is truely one of my fav songs of all time. What makes this song so great is that it gives a rare aura to it that makes it easy to listen to no matter what mood you are in. It's a little eerie, dark, poppy, catchy, fun, mellow, rock, depressing, and even happy all rolled into one. 3min and 13secs is a perfect time limit for any good song, not too long and not too short. If you haven't heard this song, buy this album, you won't be disappointed.Other highlights of this album is the mellow, slow "Big Empty" that clarifies the great variety Scott Weiland has to his musical ability to write and sing. "Vasoline" is a fast tempo in your face come at you hard rock experience that will want you begging for more. The songs, "Still Remains" and "Pretty Penny" are also catchy pop rock songs that make this such a great album.If you aren't convinced enough that STP isn't just another Pearl Jam, Soundgarden, or even Nirvana, check out this album. Core may be a replica of early 90s grunge, but Purple clearly solidifies Stone Temple Pilots as one of the great bands of the 90's and even into this decade.

"Fine place for a day full of breakdowns" yells Scott Weiland against 'Meat Plow's ear-filling riff in STP's sophomore album. One of the strongest (and most overlooked) songs on the album, it is a thundering, original fresh blast of air, despite what all the critics say about STP ripping off (admittedly superior) bands like Nirvana and Pearl Jam. It is followed by 'Vasoline', which is over before you really get a feel for it. The saving grace of 'Lounge Fly' is its mellow, acoustic midsection which is far more affecting than the louder riffery of its first half. 'Interstate Love Song' and 'Still Remains' are two different views of love, both featuring memorable riffs. Weiland's chorus line "if you should die before me ask if you could bring a friend" are the most affecting lyrics on the album. 'Pretty Penny' and 'Big Empty' are slower tracks that grow on you, but neither is a standout. 'Unglued' and 'Army Ants' are both saved by their choruses and cool guitar riffs. 'Kitchenware & Candybars' is unusual, but a decent closer. The secret track, '12 Gracious Melodies', is so ridiculous and overdone you can't help but love it. After a few listens you'll never get it out of your head. However, best of all these songs is 'Silvergun Superman', an edgy, longish (by STP's standards) epic with unique song structure and striking, whispered verses. Overall this album breaks free from the mold of other similar music. It may not rock quite as hard as Nirvana or have the realistic, personal lyrics of Pearl Jam, but it makes up for it with its melodic and fun rock music.

This album is flat out amazing, and a classic in every sense of the word. Unlike other albums at the time, this record gets even better with age. I wish STP could go back to the sound of this (and No.4) record.No label needed, just damn fine music.

"core" was hard to top.you wouldnt think that any band could outdo themselves.that is,until stone temple pilots emerged with "purple",a veritable mellow step down from "core"'s aggression and heaviness."meatplow" is a straight forward modern rock song that gets the album going."vasoline",a quick and catchy tune was the first single and really kicks the cd into high gear."interstate love song" was the mellow,hit single radio was looking for and it piloted the band to mainstream success (although not one of my favorites)."still remains"-if there is a better stone tmeple pilots track post "core",you let me know because i could listen to that song day in and day out forever.unbelieveable."silvergun superman" picks up in the wake of "meatplow" and "vasoline" while "big empty",the track made famous by "the crow" provieds soft verses and a heavy chorus."unglued",the fast punk rock song seems out of place but it is soo amazing."kitchenware and candybars" is the epic ending and although very long, it is a great mellwoed out track and fun to listen to.all in all, STP have eclipsed the greatness of "core" and their 1994 album "purple" remains one of my favorites of all time.sheer genius.

STP proves itself to be above all others, and this album is no accpetion to that.  There are no weak songs on this album, and I listen to it religiously still almost 10 years after it came out.  All of the hits are great, Interstate Love Song, Vasoline, and Big Empty, but the other songs could all be singles in themselves.  The best song on the Album and possibly my favorite song of all time is Still Remains.  Once you see these guys live, you will know they are the real deal, but this album will win you over none the less.

This is what a real american rock and roll band in this times has to be, no GNR sounds , no hair looks , not that lack of ambition for experimentation that the bands in the old concept of "rock star" were afraid to offer because they didnt wanted to jeopardize fame and mostly money they won (that era ended anyway) STP liked to mix blues, with hard rock, and alternative sounds with classic rock and roll, they incorporated all kind of percussions and acoustic and electric strings, piano sometimes, when it was about getting hard they sounded visceral, never overproduced, and never totally digitalized, lyrics were so crazy and bizarre sometimes as good rock and roll bands has to express, they were never worried about doing stupidly pretencious videos like GNR with girls , fancy cars , expensive weedings etc, etc,and GNR were a terrific band but some concepts they tried to show were so ridiculous, STP were a real rock and roll band i repeat and i find extrange scott weiland asociation with ex guns to form Velvet Revolver anyway, you need to listen "purple" wich is their best album, and you gona agree with meHM
summary: Purple is my choice when it comes about STP or grunge

reviewText: It has been years since I had this cd, reason I didn't have it cause it got stolen with the rest of my collection of cd's. I like this cd then and I like it now another great buy at a great price.

Purple goes down in my book as one of the greatest albums of my lifetime, right up there with the likes of Born To Run (Springsteen), Rubber Soul (Beatles) & Hotel California (Eagles). It is an album that all previous  and subsequent releases of theirs will be compared to.. This is the Sgt.  Pepper of the 90's. A masterpiece.

Purple was and still is my favorite STP record. It combines Led Zep riffs with monster distortion to create an amazing, melodic sound that is still 100% fresh today. STP will last forever in the minds of alternative rock fans that lived the movement.

With Purple, Stone Temple Pilots proved that they were not a flash in the pan, one hit wonder about to crash notwithstanding the success of "Sex Type Thing," "Creep," and "Wicked Garden." Success was not going to overwhelm this machine. It seems that the boys had listened to Jimmy Page's reasoning for "lots of light and shade" on many fo the Zeppelin songs and albums. Every other song either had shades of acoustic material or is entirely soft and gentle somewhere. STP did not lose any intensity by dialing down the distortion. Even the Vegas-style showtune is interesting. Fans of Core will not be disappointed and neither will fans of Led Zeppelin 3.
summary: Second Battle in the War on Grunge

reviewText: Super-produced and excruciating detail found its way into every track on  this album.  Somewhere between Pearl Jam, Green Day, and Soundgarden, Scott  Weiland and the boys of STP laid down one of grundge's last runaway smash  successes.From the opening crunch of bruising rhythm on Meat Plow to  the Vegas showtune that closes the album, STP spit out against the rock  tradition they were living.  Just a bunch of rebels led by junkie Weiland,  STP's manic riffs may have been copied, but they sure wouldn't admit to it.Either way, the music is great.  When STP really rocked out, they were  better than any other grundge band.  Finding hooks on Meat Plow and  Vasoline to open the album, STP can get any modern rock listener hooked.  By the time 90s classics, Interstate Love Song and Big Empty come along,  STP has anyone convinced that they are not only legit, but really, really  good.  The final track of the album, "Kitchenware and Candybars",  closes off the CD very well.  It also ended something.  Polished grundge  CDs started to give way to polished pop-rock CDs with a decidedly lighter  tone.  With the closing Vegas showtune, STP started to close the door on an  era that Soundgarden would slam shut not much later.This CD is the  last testament to the power grundge could contain.

The 1990's produced some of the best rock music since rock and roll's inception with a few groups creating some deep and flawless masterpieces. Especially those groups whose sophmore alblums pefected the aura and art tried on their blockbuster debut alblums. STP being one of such for the mid-90's with "Purple" and it's singles. This alblum is ridiculously perfect in all for what it is. It fully represented the 90's era of gloom and honesty. Unfortunately it also fortified the sad truth in the art of a rockstar. This alblum is one of the best examples of a prelude to destruction. Scott Weiland's poetic magic only explained through massive amounts of drugs and booze. With his memoirs coming out soon, to buy this particular alblum will give you a bigger scope of why that man should have died after making it. If not, buy it only for the track "Big Empty" and nothing else. It captures the entire idea behind grunge/alternative rock before the previous died and the latter turned into mainstream pop garbage. Buy it for the truth. Conversations do kill.

"Purple", STP's sophomore effort, clears away the stereotypical "slump".  This is perhaps their greatest work.  The musical maturity of the band is so apparent on this album.  Taking the time to  experiment with arrangements and sounds, STP produced a classic.  The power  of "Vasoline" is equally balanced by the ballad-sounds of  "Interstate Love Song", and the funky "Pretty Penny".  Such a great music album, "Purple" is an incredible follow up to  "Core".  This is an STP fan staple, and if you like somewhat  offbeat music with a conventional foundation, you'll love  "Purple".

I bought this CD for one reason: "Vasoline." I love that song! However, upon further listening, I found that each and every song was brilliant in its own way. From the hard-edged, organized insanity of songs  like "Army Ants," "Meatplow," and "Vasoline,"  STP goes into softer territory with "Big Empty," and "Pretty  Penny."  There's something for everybody out there. If at first you  only like a couple of songs, force yourself to listen to the whole CD--you  will love it!  Oh, and don't forget the secret song after #11  ("Kitchenware and Candy Bars")-it's hilarious!
summary: Purple takes you to the edge and back

reviewText: STP achieved great success with Core, and still continued strong with their second album Purple. The band looked towards other influences for their second album, and the songs were more elaborate and not as one-dimensional like they were on Core, although Core ruled. Their hard rock roots still are evident on Meatplow, Vasoline, and Interstate Love Song, but they dabbled in many other sounds. They wrote some acoustic songs like Pretty Penny and Kitchenware & Candybars (perhaps their most riveting song), and experimented with instruments like the mellotron (the intro to Army Ants), and various percussion instruments. It's hard to say whcih album is better Core or Purple, but both are worth picking up.
summary: A lotmore diverse than Core, and just as strong

reviewText: album arrived in great shape. one of the first albums I bought with my own money, but even without the personal sentimental value, I think any fan of 90's rock can appreciate the great hooks and creative writing on Purple! love the way Silvergun Superman falls apart into beautiful chaos...

When Stone Temple Pilots hit it big in 1993 with their debut "Core", the band's rather obvious attempt to align its image with the then-popular grunge scene earned them derision.
